This course will introduce basic concepts and skills associated with painting. You will engage with a variety of materials and methods of painting as a means of art making. The focused, practical experiences in this course provide an understanding of painting's specific processes and creative possibilities. By the end of the course, you will have an insight into the expectations and versatility of this discipline.

contentlets.keywords: art,photography,photomedia,image-based practice,photographic studio practice,fine art photography,contemporary photographic practice,introduction to photography,introductory photography,camera obscura,digital photography,foundation photography,first year photography,21st century photography,interdisciplinary image-based practice
contentlets.description:
MAKING: PHOTOGRAPHY introduces students to the experience of working with Photography and photographic-based practices, focusing on the image and surrounding concepts within a contemporary context. Students investigate current contemporary art practice and its historical origins within the context of the Photographic studio and theory.

Emphasis is on the development of a keen critical awareness by looking at the content and context of contemporary art and culture. The questions of intent, content, process and context are explored in relation to the production of project-based works that lay the foundations for the development of the individual student's artistic language.
contentlets.title: Making: Photography

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART1313 - Making: Printmaking","description":"

This course will introduce the creative concepts and practical skills associated with contemporary printmaking practice. Students will investigate, using a combination of experimental and traditional approaches, the materials and methodologies of two printmaking techniques – matrix strategies via relief printing and screen methods via serigraphy.


By providing opportunities to imaginatively interpret the creative possibilities of the print, students will gain an insight into the expectations and versatility of printmaking as an artistic practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"527e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961904","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Patterns in Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project is in two parts:

1.     For this project students will be required to research an artist who uses patterns and repetition in their work, and write 200 words about how the artist selected the patterns he works with and how the pattern relates to the ideas presented within the work.

2.     Students will be required to devise an image in 3 panels (or a series of 3 images) that are based on the use of pattern and repetition to emphasize the ideas you are working with.  Students are not limited to only the use of patterns in your image, line-work, stand-alone images and half-tones can be incorporated in order for the image to be resolved successfuly. Students will use screenprinting techniques including photographic stencils, handcut stencils and direct-to-screen stencils to create the assessable artwork.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"127e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5e7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d27e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e7e307fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Dual Likeness","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required to present for assessment a journal documenting your research, experiments and processes as well as un-resolved ‘support’ material to demonstrate experimentation with the medium.  The journal may be presented as loose items, it doesn’t necessarily have to be in book form. This will form 10% of the final mark for this Assessment Task.

This project is in two parts:

  1. Develop a monochrome linocut self portrait that engages with contemporary notions of portraiture based on a self-depictive strategy.  Provide a 100 word written statement outlining the concepts and research, which led to the development of the portrait.
    • Block size: At least 30x30 cm
    • Edition size: 4
  3. Develop a multi-colour reduction linocut (at least 4 colours) that utilizes a non-likeness strategy what you consider to be crucial elements of your self.
    • Block size: 20x30cm
    • Edition of 1 or often described as a Unique state print.

Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

During Assessment in Week 8.

By providing opportunities to imaginatively interpret the creative possibilities of the print, students will gain an insight into the expectations and versatility of printmaking as an artistic practice.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART1314 - Making: Installation Art","description":"

This studio course enables you to study the foundations of sculpture, performance, installation and environmental art, and introduces the skills, processes, concepts and visual language that will support you in future creative work.


Students undertake a series of projects that develop critical awareness, interpretive skills and research methods to enhance their practice. 


The interdisciplinary nature of contemporary sculptural practice is emphasised and the course supports a diversity of experiences, including producing works using time, light, spatiality, acoustic and digital sound, collaboration and performance, as well as exploratory applications of traditional sculptural forms, assemblages and methodologies.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a011cdf3db391c50eb6b147a3a961973","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound installation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to install their artwork in an appropriate site for assessment. The following criteria is applied - 

  1. Completion of research of Sydney environments as soundscapes to inform the .
  2. Ability to creatively combine of sound, acoustic &/or digital with a  sculptural, site specific installation.
  3. Creative exploration of  ironic combinations of the mundane and spectacular as the theme for an artwork.

      Throughout the work in progress the lecturer critiques the progress of students' artwork in tutorials with group discussions at strategic times. At assessment each student receives feedback from the lecturer and peer at the student's presentation of their artwork  followed by written critical  feedback from the lecturer with advice on how to improve their artwork and class participation. Marks of each of the assessment's criteria supplied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ac11cdf3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1411cdf3db391c50eb6b147a3a96194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Environmental art","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"Students install their work in a location of their choice observing Health & Safety considerations. ASSESSMENT CRITERIA

1.    Create an intervention in a selected site that is generated by memory, or historic, cultural or social references

2.   Create a ephemeral, or temporary artwork that interacts with the natural environment, its natural forces,  its changes over time, or the sea front's built environment.

3.   Ability to observe protocols and etiquette involved in creating ephemeral, public artworks.


Throughout work in progress the lecturer critiques the progress of students' artwork in tutorials with group discussions at strategic times. At assessment each student receives feedback from the lecturer and peer at the student's presentation of their artwork  followed by written critical  feedback from the lecturer with advice on how to improve their artwork and class participation. Marks of each of the assessment's criteria supplied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2411cdf3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5c11cdf3db391c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The encoding of objects","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

PRESENTATION FOR ASSESSMENT:

1. Should the work be exhibited on the floor, on a plinth, in a particular site, on the wall, worn on the body, a component or agent in a performance, manipulated by the viewer?

 2. Give the artwork a title, and write an artist’s statement of intent (100 words):

a)      A title identifies the artwork, and may give the viewer an entré into interpretations of the work.

b)     How were the found objects encoded individually?

c)     What is the dialogue created between the two objects you have used to make the artwork?

CRITERIA FOR ASSESSMENT

1.     Demonstration of your ability to analyse and interpret the cultural significance of vernacular objects.

2.     Imaginatively create conceptual relationship/s between two objects, to form a dialogue.

3.     Consideration of the appropriate presentation of the artwork for public exhibition, including a title, and an artist’s statement of intent.


Throughout the work in progress the lecturer critiques the progress of students' artworks in tutorials with group feedback at strategic times. At assessment each student receives feedback from the lecturer and peers in front of the student's presentation of their artwork  followed by written critical  feedback from the lecturer with advice on how to improve their artwork, their written work and their class participation. Marks of each of the assessment's criteria supplied.

contentlets.keywords: art,sculpture,installation art,performance art,environmental art,sound installation,inter disciplinary art,contemporary art practice,assemblage,visual art research
contentlets.description:
This studio course enables you to study the foundations of sculpture, performance, installation and environmental art, and introduces the skills, processes, concepts and visual language that will support you in future creative work.

Students undertake a series of projects that develop critical awareness, interpretive skills and research methods to enhance their practice. 

The interdisciplinary nature of contemporary sculptural practice is emphasised and the course supports a diversity of experiences, including producing works using time, light, spatiality, acoustic and digital sound, collaboration and performance, as well as exploratory applications of traditional sculptural forms, assemblages and methodologies.

The aim of this course is to enable the student to develop skills and an intuitive awareness of aesthetic values in painting so that the student can use the discipline of painting as a means of individual artistic expression. The student will explore theoretical concepts and develop relevant skills as a basis for making paintings. The student will undertake projects aimed at encouraging an individual, creative and professional approach to painting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e941c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Secondary Source Painting","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This task requires a creative response that focuses on the interpretation of secondary source material (defined as ‘found’ or ‘pre-existing’ images created by another individual or entity), including images and text from newspapers, magazines, books, Fine-Art reproductions, video/film stills, photography, industrial and commercial graphics, illustrations, and computer-generated imagery.

Students will respond to their found image(s) through a series of processes, translating their 2- dimensional source material into a 3-dimensional structure, then into a painting. For the purpose of this task, a 3-dimensional response might take the form of an image or collage (manipulated or composed of low-relief, projective, folded, bent, creased elements), an assemblage, construction, model or diorama. The student may paint directly from the model, or photograph the model and refer only to the photograph whilst painting, mindful that any method employed will influence the appearance of the final image. In this sense, ‘Secondary Source Painting’ is a protracted mediation of the subject, and can involve several degrees of separation between the ‘original’ source material and the student's painting.

Through the processes and conventions of ‘sculptural’ fabrication, photography, and painting, students will develop creative strategies through which they can deconstruct, reconstruct, transform, interpret and critique their secondary source image(s). Students will be mindful of aesthetics, content, and meaning while addressing a spectrum of issues such as form, composition, materiality, spatiality, scale, lighting (modeling, light and shadow), and depth of field (focus and lack of focus). The fluidity of authorship, notions of ‘originality’, and the establishment of meaning through the modification, recycling or remixing of cultural forms is also a feature of this task. For assessment you will be required to present all relevant found image(s), model(s), photographs (if applicable), and painting. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2141c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a941c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9541c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Painting From Direct Observation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Painting a still life from direct observation, two small ‘canvases’ will be completed: each will depict the same two or three objects but with different compositional viewpoints. The objects (of the student’s choice) might be similar to each other (e.g. three teapots) or contrasted (e.g. star fish and mechanical apparatus). Aspects to consider when selecting the objects are colour, pattern, texture, scale, form, materiality, simplicity or complexity, their decorativeness or utility, and even their symbolic or personal associations. Pictorial concerns of cropping, composition, scale, and viewpoint will be a focal point of both paintings, with contrasts between: (I) the ‘macro’ and ‘micro’ viewpoint — in this instance, defined as a view that is all-encompassing and broad in scope, versus a more closely focused view with small- scale sections made large, even to the point of abstraction — and (II) ‘open’ and ‘closed’ compositions — defined as compositions where forms extend outside of the picture plane, versus those where objects and forms are largely (and often formally) contained within the frame. An introduction to painting techniques and materiality is also a feature of this assessment task, with a range of approaches including preparation of a ground, sketching, under-painting, painting wet-on-wet, wet-on-dry, and glazing, to be considered by the student. An introduction to colour theory will also allow the student to mix colours to appropriately reflect the range of tones and hues within the still life. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6d41c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a541c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e141c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dd41c537db391c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site/Place","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are to research and document a site/place familiar to them; an interior, exterior, domestic, urban, or landscape scene they can make repeat visits to. The emphasis is on the collection of PRIMARY source material, i.e. research and documentation including notes, rubbings, plein-air paintings and sketches undertaken by the student in situ. Photographic documentation is not permitted. In contrast to 'Secondary Source Painting', all images that derive from the subject in the development of the work are to be entirely of the student's own authorship. Students will then paint a studio-based work using this primary research.

Students must consider how direct experience of the subject informs the meaning of their work. For example, the conceptual rationale for such a process of direct experience could engage with concepts of 'connectedness to land' or the notion of 'home' and its associated themes of autobiography and identity. Questions regarding the ‘nature’ and ‘mode’ of engagement with the subject are significant, for example, being mindful of the appropriateness of different types of investigations, the gathering of different types of research material, and the various observational, perceptual, intellectual, or emotional experiences with a subject that will meaningfully contribute to the creation of a painting. Students may choose to explore phenomenological/perceptual themes in response to experiential sensations linked to site/place. Phenomena and atmospherics related to light, environment, and climate, for example, may be relevant in this respect, whether the site is ‘natural’ or ‘built’.

Consider: Appropriate types of site-specific research and documentation that will facilitate the development and completion of a larger studio based image; the role of visual and written ‘records’, ‘memory’ and the imagination; formal attributes of the artwork; use of materials and techniques; style and aesthetics; development of personal, spiritual, cultural, social significance and meaning.

Materials: watercolour / acrylic / alkyd / oil / mixed media / etc. as appropriate.
Supports: Stretched canvas, canvas board, primed Masonite, MDF board, oil sketch paper, etc. (size appropriate to your creative aims and objectives), a single or multi-paneled artwork. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e541c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dd41c537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART1501.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"SART1502 - Drawing","description":"

This course will enable students to develop a command of drawing as a visual arts discipline and to relate the art of drawing to other areas of creative endeavour. The student will explore various aspects of drawing and develop competence and confidence in drawing. The student will undertake exercises which will emphasise drawing as a means of creative expression, and also as a tool of research in the visual arts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"77414937db391c50eb6b147a3a96191a","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Understanding Tone, Form and Volume","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In this assessment task, students will use tone to create the pictorial illusion of ‘three-dimensionality’. Through a process of intense observation, students will enhance their ability to create volumetric form; identify reflected light on objects; differentiate planes and solids by establishing tonal relationships; moreover, express tonal grades across light, mid-tone, and dark objects, and lit or shadow areas. Modeling techniques may include hatching, cross-hatching, contour hatching, block tone, and working from dark to light by employing an eraser as a drawing tool. The assessment task will run for three (3) days and will include one (1) home project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"37414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f7414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"23410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exploring Colour, Surface, and Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

While focusing on colour, surface, and form, this project will introduce students to various materials and working processes, expand their drawing practice and style, and develop their compositional skills. Through a process of intense observation, students will visually represent structure and surface by identifying and responding to variations in the tones and hues of objects and their shadows, reflected light, and both matte and lustrous, plain and patterned, smooth and textured surfaces. Students will use various drawing techniques, materials (such as pastels, pencils, and watercolours) and a colour palette that allows them to express these subtleties. This assessment task runs for four (4) days. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"73414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f7414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"23414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing from Direct Observation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will draw from direct observation to gain an understanding of the conceptual and perceptual challenges of representing three-dimensional objects on a two-dimensional ground. Students will be introduced to basic perceptual analysis strategies such as measuring, plotting, gridding, using positive and negative space, and methods of construction drawing. Concepts such as proportion, viewpoint, foreshortening, and perspective will be explored and visually applied. The assessment task will run for three (3) days and will include one (1) home project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"73414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f7414937db391c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e7410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART1502.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

1","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/DART1230","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"DART1230","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART1641 - Video Art","description":"

These courses offer students the opportunity to gain an awareness of the nature and variety of experiences included in the television area, to appreciate the specific qualities and potential of the video and electronic media and to acquire the technical, intellectual and creative skills necessary for the creation of original video work. By exploration of a theoretical overview and the development of relevant skills the student will formulate and implement an extensive study of a field of practice within the area of Video.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f751c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Virtual/Real","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Project a moving video image onto a space, person, object, building, etc. The video should be a single shot and silent. The projector must be stationary.

The moving projected image (virtual) will interact with object or space the it is projected onto (real). Aspects to consider may include: the architectural, an action, context, social space, the sculptural, the abstract, formal space, the doppleganger, the double take, the function of space, stasis, incongruity etc. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2351c937db391c50eb6b147a3a961997","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Loop","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Loop: Seamlessly repeating, merging beginning and end in cyclical continuity.

This project aims to develop students understanding of formal and conceptual circularity in the practice of Video Art. Students are to create a short single channel video work that explores the structure and concept of The Loop. There are a number of things to consider in this project:

1.
Formal and structural qualities of The Loop.
The loop can be described as a sequence of shots or a single shot that can be viewed from any point within its duration and at it’s end return to its starting point in seamless repetition. There is no beginning or end.

2.
Conceptual approaches to the idea of The Loop. There are many complex themes resonant with, and are inherent to, the f orm of the loop. Some of these may include: time, the natural environment, history, social systems, human behavior.

3.
Loops must be presented as a H.264 720p Quicktime file.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b751c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6b51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Video Installation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Each student will produce a video artwork viewed /experienced as an installation. Alternatively, the work may also be presented as a live event (performance). The artwork must take into consideration the characteristics of the space in which it is presented. The video must play a part in the artwork. It does not have to be the major part, however you must demonstrate how you have integrated the video into your chosen space.

Students should consider:

Context and use of location.
The role of the visitor in relation to the media (recorded or live) in space. Sound (or silence)
Live and/or pre-recorded elements and how they impact on the location. Concerns, issues and content articulated through the work.

All work must be within the genre of fine art practice. Informational, commercial, graphic design, advertising and music clips may not be presented unless it is to challenge these forms.

It is strongly suggested that students are aware of the spatial and equipment restrictions that are inevitable in assessment week. It will be the student's responsibility to ensure that the necessary equipment and space for their installation is reserved for Assessment (book early). It is also advised that the student rehearse the installation in the planned location at least once prior to assessment. If you are experiencing problems obtaining equipment or securing a location for your project, inform your lecturer prior to assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f351c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a351c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART1641.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course allows students to develop the basic principles and techniques of intaglio printing, including etching, drypoint and engraving. Through investigation and selection students will demonstrate an understanding of the technical means and aesthetic qualities of the original print. Students will attain a level of competence in a chosen process and develop their potential as creative artists in the printmaking medium in the context of contemporary practice.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2400 - Painting and Materiality","description":"

Painting and Materiality facilitates an exploration of painting processes, materials and supports, in order to broaden your understanding of the language of painting and its possibilities. The course will cover mark making, paint handling, collage, assemblage, found object, and new materialities that may be used in painting. You will investigate a variety of conventional and unconventional methodologies that make up the extensive branch of knowledge we understand to be painting. You will also consider the medium's agency to convey meaning, its currency and potential to evolve. You will experiment with the substances and substrates of painting in relation to contemporary aesthetics.


The knowledge acquired in this studio course can be applied across a range of related BFA(Hons) and BMA(Hons) courses. This course complements the Year 2 Painting courses SART2401 Painting and Technology, SART2402 Painting and the Body and SART2403 Painting: Space, Time and Place and prepares students for more advanced studies in the Year 3 level.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"737e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Image/Object","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment task requires students to produce a body of work that negotiates the relationship between objects and images through painting. What is an object? What is an image? How are the meanings of images and objects constructed? The image/object relationship might be understood as a dichotomy between virtual/actual, illusion/reality, or absence/presence.

Feedback is provided by the lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2b7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Atemporal Painting","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

For the ‘Atemporal Painting’ assessment task, students are required to visit the Art Gallery of New South Wales (AGNSW) and independently investigate one of the paintings on display in the general collection. Students are to research as much relevant information as possible about the artwork, the artist, and the context in which it was created.

Feedback is provided by the lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"777e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Composite Imaging","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are to produce 12 collages, one of which is to form the basis of a subsequent painting. Collages are to incorporate found materials. The aim is to develop a body of work that explores the potential for observed gestures, marks and traces to expand the vocabulary of techniques in your painting practice. Student's material exploration should culminate in a scaled-up painting (minimum dimension 60cm/ 24”) of proportions that match the collage you choose to work from.

Feedback is provided by the lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2b7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb7e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a77e707fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART2400.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2401 - Painting and Technology","description":"

This course encourages you to consider technology's relationship to the evolution of painting through both historical and contemporary contexts. You will explore the influence of lens-based technologies and the proliferation of images generated through mechanical and electronic media. You will investigate the impact of technology's effect in developing alternative perceptual and material processes for contemporary painting. You will employ strategies of imaging, mediation and manipulation to experiment with new possibilities for painting in the digital age. 


The knowledge acquired in this studio course can be applied across a range of related BFA(Hons) and BMA(Hons) courses. This course complements the Year 2 Painting courses and prepares students for more advanced studies in the Year 3 level. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"498eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Breaches of Continuity","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

‘Breaches of Continuity’ investigates analogue, mechanical, and digital interference and transformation of an image. The aim is to develop an artwork that explores the potential of an image or images undergoing mediation through multiple aesthetic and conceptual interventions, and material and technological processes. What are the visual possibilities when creating or triggering—in a calculated or uncontrolled manner—deterioration, glitch, and distortion effects? How can painting interact with technology in order to articulate these effects? What are the potentials for creating images that are coherent or incoherent; that have a sense of degradation and fragmentation, or visual continuity and unity; that have figurative vestiges or move into the realm of abstraction?

You will explore this Assessment Task by responding to the following processes and ideas:

            • Deterioration: imperfection in production and reproduction

            • Distortion: mechanical and digital effects

            • Glitch: error as aesthetic

Preliminary experiments will be undertaken. Processes of distortion, deterioration, and glitch will be iteratively applied to a selected image or images, compositionally developed, and translated into a painting or mixed media artwork. You should consider the resolution of the artwork in relation to its synthesis of concepts, forms, materials and techniques.

This Task also requires you to submit an ‘artist’s file’ containing images of your original studio experiments/processes and final studio image. This PDF file should include: 

  1. approx. 5 pages documenting the depth and breadth of your early experiments and processes—scale images accordingly (they may even be thumbnails approx. 4cm high if you have undertaken multiple iterations of one image); 
  2. approx. 3 pages of images and text documenting artists (historical and contemporary), manuals, references, and journal articles you have looked at/sought inspiration from to contextualize your practice; 
  3. a 1-page statement approx. 250 words about the final artwork you have created that expresses: the concept (ideas), contextualization (synopsis of artists, references, journal articles), and methodologies (your processes) underpinning it. This page will also include the title of the final artwork and the details/medium of the work, e.g. Oil, acrylic, collage, on oil sketch paper, 60 x 90 cm.
  4. a single page with an image of the final artwork.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"018eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4d8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c18eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3c8eb07fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mediated Image","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This project investigates the theme of ‘Mediated Image’. How can contemporary painting practices develop from—or in response to—visual information sourced or generated by print, photographic, and digital media? An overview will be provided that establishes both historical and contemporary contexts for this interplay of painting with images sourced from newspapers, magazines, Fine-Art reproductions, video/film stills, industrial and commercial graphics, illustrations, and the digital realm (essentially, any type of two-dimensional image). 

You will consider the nexus between creative and aesthetic frameworks, the subject and nature of source images, and the materials and processes of painting. Your investigations will be informed by propositions, concepts, and strategies of critique, mediation and post-production; this includes homogeneous and heterogeneous citation, appropriation, (re-)mixing, and (re-)interpretation.

For assessment purposes, artworks and ‘studies’ produced outside of class and in studio-intensive sessions will be presented as a portfolio(a suite of creative works demonstrating various ideas, processes, techniques, and materials). Studio-intensive sessions will support and expand your understanding of the technologies and mediation processes available to you.

You will employ strategies of imaging, mediation and manipulation to experiment with new possibilities for painting in the digital age. 

The knowledge acquired in this studio course can be applied across a range of related BFA(Hons) and BMA(Hons) courses. This course complements the Year 2 Painting courses and prepares students for more advanced studies in the Year 3 level.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SART2403","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2403 - Painting: Space, Time and Place","description":"

In this course, you will explore the roles of spatiality, temporality and site in relation to representation in contemporary painting. Historically, painting has been an innovative medium through which to reconfigure spatial and temporal awareness. You will explore painting in relation to contemporary contexts of motion, mapping and location. Questions as to how contemporary painting responds to your experiences of space, time and place in the contexts of global mobility, connectivity, and multiple dimensionality of mediums will provide you with inspiration for different bodies of work.


The course can be taken as part of a Painting stream in the BFA or BMA. It can also be taken as an elective course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"db8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961928","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Spacing Surface","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The aim of this task is to draw attention to how space is constructed and presented via painted surfaces. Through studio experimentation in ‘research clusters’, you will explore how light, mediums, vision, perspective and composition can express space differently.

This task requires experimentation, building onknowledge and skills gained from the study of analogue and optical devices used in traditional painting to describe space. The focus is on how groups can think creatively about how to translate space onto surface. Experimenting in the studio with the relationship between two and three dimensions, groups will use this process to show a deeper understanding of space.

In groups of four or five students, you are to design, build and demonstrate a ‘painting machine’ that transcribes space onto a surface. For this task, ‘machine’ can mean any device, process or apparatus comprised of parts that work together to perform a task. The elements of the ‘machine’can be mechanical OR ephemeral OR human OR any combination of these. Groups must collaboratively produce at least two painted surfaces using their machine, and each individual must independently produce a third work using the same machine.

Things to consider:

·       How is the experience of space different from pictorial space?

·       How does light produce space in an image?

·       Which qualities of 3D space are untranslatable onto 2D?

·       How can images of space be blended or composite?

Each group will have 10-minutes to show and discuss their studio work in class. Groups should explain the experimental methods used, describe/demonstrate how the ‘machine’ works and show physical ‘paintings’, objects or models that resulted from experimentation. Groups should highlight the compositional, contextual and conceptual painting strategies taken, informed by research into historical and contemporary painting. Groups should also emphasise how they have interpreted experiences of space, and how they have resolved differences between perception and presentation of space.

Individual members of the group are each required to submit a PDF of images and text (300 words max) that summarises the methods and materials used during the experimentation process, along with a description of your own contribution to the group, plus critical reflection on your individual work. Each student is assessed individually.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"478e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"df8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Timing Motion","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

his Assessment Task asks you to consider time and motion from the perspective of studio-based representation. Building on investigations of space in Task 1, you are to avoid describing movement by merely plotting spatial displacements of objects on a two-dimensional surface. Experiment with paint, transparency, blur, focus, trace, overlap and illusions of movement to investigate the time-space relation.

Things to consider:

·       How do objects in a painting appear fast or slow?

·       How does your choice of surface and medium react to different forces of movement?

·       How is the illusion of weight given in painting?

·       What is the relation of time and duration to space?

·       What kind of ‘presence’ can objects and figures have in paintings?

·       How is rhythm implied or enacted by painting?

You must produce three resolved paintings that address the relation between time and motion, informed by studio experimentation and process.

The paintings should be accompanied by a small selection of support material and a 50-word statement summarising your research and process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"938e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"df8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"478e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fictional Maps and Places","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Images of ‘place’ are increasingly multifaceted compared with pictorial traditions like landscape painting. Artists have critiqued representations of place, site and mapping in their practices for decades. Many contemporary artists explore complex representations of place involving processes of ‘mapping’ with traditional methods and/or emerging technologies.

This Assessment Task requires you to produce a resolved ‘map’ of a fictional place or event.You can critically and creatively interpret what constitutes a ‘map’ for this task. A map can be any symbolic representation that highlights relationships between certain elements in a given space. You may like to start with a real place and imagine a fictional event that happened to radically change how people can move around / negotiate the place. This place could be a local park, a city block, a river, a shopping mall or the UNSW Art & Design campus.

You may describe this fictional place by painting, collage, assemblage or other studio based methods. Your process may involve a mixture of photography, drawing, painting and/or digital technology. You should research conceptual and experimental ways of ‘mapping’ place based on historical and contemporary approaches of other artists. The challenge is for you to map a place according to your imagination.

Things to consider:

·       Which objects and elements of a place should be highlighted or edited out?

·       How can signs and symbols represent events in time?

·       How does the medium of paint provoke imagination in the studio?

·       How can an attitude to place be communicated through the expressive use of mediums?

Through your work for this task, you might acknowledge the history of a place, describe the present, and project into the future. Access to the unreal and fictional is unlimited in the painted space. Painting allows for creative re-imaginings. The ‘maps’ produced for this task should be bold, inventive, and subversive interpretations of place.

The work should be accompanied by a small selection of support material and a short 50-word statement summarising your concept and research.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"df8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f8e347fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART2403.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
In this course, you will explore the roles of spatiality, temporality and site in relation to representation in contemporary painting. Historically, painting has been an innovative medium through which to reconfigure spatial and temporal awareness. You will explore painting in relation to contemporary contexts of motion, mapping and location. Questions as to how contemporary painting responds to your experiences of space, time and place in the contexts of global mobility, connectivity, and multiple dimensionality of mediums will provide you with inspiration for different bodies of work.

The course can be taken as part of a Painting stream in the BFA or BMA. It can also be taken as an elective course.
contentlets.title: Painting: Space, Time and Place

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2404 - Printmaking: Etching","description":"

SART2404 Printmaking - Etching offers studio-based instruction in a range of etching techniques. These include matrix development using hardground line, aquatint, lift ground, drypoint, collagraph and deep-etch methods as well as several printing strategies that include basic colour methods. You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print. 


This 2nd year introductory studio course is part of a four-course specialist Printmaking stream and may also be taken as an elective where places are available.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a84729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Word Games","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task requires students to produce an editioned image developed from the idea of an unexpected juxtaposition. Using the strategy of chance, students will experience an unpredictable way of sparking the process of applying artistic concepts for content development in a print-related work. The Assessment Task is also an introduction to the matrix (plate) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) and an understanding of Printmaking in its interdisciplinary context. It may also include some engagement with Relief techniques as they apply to Intaglio printing methods.

Students will be required to discuss their work in progress in class through both individual consultations and participation in group critiques.

Students will seek to establish verbal communication skills appropriate to their developing artistic practice and the processes encountered in a number of forums. This will include individual consultation with the lecturer or active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d44729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"004729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Evolution","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task will encourage students to continue to develop their knowledge and practical experience in the diverse range of methodologies found in both direct and indirect Intaglio printing techniques, but focus on a different procedural approach to image making. In contrast to the conceptual method deployed in Assessment Task 1 students will be required to produce a series of images using a more kinesthetic strategy that facilitates the exploration of change and transition through the development of a printed image that evolves from one state to another.

Evolution will require students to begin by creating up to three A4 drawings using brush and ink, charcoal or a broad-based marking pen. These images can be created using any theme that has a particular personal relevance. After reviewing the research material (Drawings) students will use one or a combination of these to form the basis of an etching that will be created using a brush using the liftground (Sugar-lift) method, which can then incorporate Aquatint or Open-bite processes. Once the plate has been developed it must be printed in an edition onto archival stock using the conventions introduced in Assessment Task 1. Once complete students will then be required to make significant changes to that image using processes introduced in Assessment Task 1 or methods demonstrated that may also include erasure techniques like scraping and burnishing. The image on the plate needs to progress both technically and conceptually and once complete it should be editioned. This process then needs to be carried out a third time, similarly making substantial changes from the second state of the image. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"604729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d44729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"104729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This Assessment Task allows students to continue to investigate the Etching workshop techniques that have been established to further develop the skills required in the interpretation of artistic concepts. Each student will initiate an idea that then leads to the production of one printed artwork within the scope of the intaglio and relief printmedia explored in this course. Students may consider applying techniques previously encountered in the Printmaking Stream and may also incorporate skills developed in other courses in their Program, so that they begin to consider the potential of a broader trans-disciplinary practice. Ideas informing the development of this artwork are to be declared in a written proposal, the form of which is addressed in the briefing notes for Assessment Task 2.

Ideas informing the development of this artwork are to be declared in a 500 word written proposal and 5 min presentation to the class. Students will be allotted presentation dates in week 1. Written proposals are due to be submitted via Moodle before the start of class on the day of the presentation.

contentlets.description:
SART2404 Printmaking - Etching offers studio-based instruction in a range of etching techniques. These include matrix development using hardground line, aquatint, lift ground, drypoint, collagraph and deep-etch methods as well as several printing strategies that include basic colour methods. You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print. 

This 2nd year introductory studio course is part of a four-course specialist Printmaking stream and may also be taken as an elective where places are available.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2405 - Printmaking: Relief Printing","description":"

SART2405 Printmaking: Relief Printing offers studio-based instruction in a range of relief printing and intaglio matrix based techniques. Participants will learn about the relief applications of linocut, woodcut, relief etching and collagraph based methods that work independently or in combination with other printing processes.      You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print. 


This 2nd year introductory studio course is offered as an elective. It can be taken on its own or  provides the preparation for more advanced printmaking study.    

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9d4769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interiors","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task will encourage students to continue to develop their knowledge and practical experience of the methodologies found in Relief Printing techniques, extending the methods deployed in Assessment Task 1, by exploring the reduction technique. This is a relief printing technique where multiple applications of colour can be applied in the construction of an image from a lino block (matrix). Created from one block only, whites are initially cut and then inked with the first required colour, which is transferred by hand or via a press onto the chosen paper stock. Once this has been completed onto all your sheets of paper more surface area is cut away, hence the term "reduced", and a second colour is printed over the top of the first layer, then onward with more layers to create a completed image. Usually, the lightest colour of the design is printed first. Because of the protracted nature of this technique students will need to apply skills in planning, systems of registration and time management in the resolution of the final image.

Interiors can be interpreted on many levels from a macro reading of environmental concerns to a micro level of cellular proportions, or an emotional play of the unseen depths found within. An interior may be created to reflect a deeper personal or cultural issue, becoming a metaphor for a sense of belonging or identity.  Consider the significance of your interior and how your interpretation of it might engage with a contemporary audience. This may involve multiple prints to create a sense of environment or an interior could be created by physically folding, pleating or making a 3 D object.

Students will continue to develop verbal communication skills appropriate to their evolving artistic practice and the processes encountered during individual consultation with the lecturer or in group critiques.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"554769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"054769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This Assessment Task allows students to continue to investigate the Relief Printing workshop techniques that have been established to further develop the skills required in the interpretation of artistic concepts. Each student will initiate an idea that then leads to the production of one printed artwork within the scope of the Relief printmedia explored in this course.

Students may consider applying techniques previously encountered in the Printmaking Stream and may also incorporate skills developed in other courses in their Program, so that they begin to consider the potential of a broader trans- disciplinary practice.

Ideas informing the development of this artwork are to be declared in a 500 word written proposal and 5 min presentation to the class. Students will be allotted presentation dates in week 1. Written proposals are due to be submitted via Moodle before the start of class on the day of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"054769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"514769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"914769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d4769f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Visual Dialogues","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task requires students to produce an editioned image developed from a response to a juxtaposition between objects, each of which can be endowed with an emotional connection through visual, kinaesthetic and even auditory associations at significant times one’s life. This creates memories generated through experiences that may well represent more than what they seem. Using the ideas derived from these cognitive relationships, the creative potential of meaning will be explored by placing two objects together to influence a spatial relationship and spark the process of applying artistic concepts for content development in a print- related work. The Assessment Task is also an introduction to the matrix (block) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) and an understanding of Printmaking in its interdisciplinary context.

Students will learn and apply a range of core relief principles, beginning with cutting techniques in lino block production, and then engagement with printing options that will lead to the exploration of different materials and methodologies.

Students will seek to establish verbal communication skills appropriate to their developing artistic practice and the processes encountered in a number of forums. This will include individual consultation with the lecturer or active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others.

Participants will learn about the relief applications of linocut, woodcut, relief etching and collagraph based methods that work independently or in combination with other printing processes.      You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print. 

This 2nd year introductory studio course is offered as an elective. It can be taken on its own or  provides the preparation for more advanced printmaking study.

SART2407 Printmaking: Screenprinting offers studio-based instruction in screenprinting techniques to create images using hand drawn, photo-generated and colour separation methods. You will be encouraged to experiment with printing strategies onto various papers and other substrates that could work independently or in combination with other printing methods.  You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e29eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"This Assessment Task links an analysis of print related history and practice with an idea initiated by each student within the scope of the screen printing media explored in this course as well as potentially linking with lithographic, photo generated and digital techniques. It requires each student to write a 400 word proposal outlining the content, medium and format of the artwork/s that will be submitted for assessment, focusing on a description of your ideas. It is expected that you will develop an awareness of the place and diversity of printmaking in contemporary art practice and build knowledge of historical issues with particular emphasis on those that continue to inform current conceptual philosophies. Consequently, this project will include the research of at least 3 print artists and the exploration of the theoretical, technical and critical issues that underpin their work, addressing how their approach to subject, genre, content and aesthetics aligns with or differs from your own. The development of research skills is crucial in the foundation of an individual studio practice, so your proposal needs to be coherent conceptually, demonstrate pertinent research and needs to show evidence of applied knowledge about your selected artists. Students will make a presentation of their intentions as well as an overview of the work of the 3 print artists selected prior to the commencement of their Self-Directed Project. In this Assessment Task students will investigate workshop techniques in the area of screen printing, preferably in combination with other printmaking processes, leading to a development of skills in the interpretation of artistic concepts within the restraints and possibilities of the media. In this Assessment Task students will apply research written and verbal communication skills to the organisation, execution and critical evaluation of ideas and procedures in printmedia, relative to current theory and practice. Graduate Attributes: understanding of their discipline in its interdisciplinary context. capable of effective communication in expressing values, approaches and opinions in a variety of forms concerning their practice and the work of others. collaborative team workers who are enterprising, innovative and creative. capable of effective communication in expressing values, approaches and opinions in a variety of forms concerning their practice and the work of others.
Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) both individually during studio sessions and via group critiques at several stages before, during and after the execution of the project.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a9eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"969eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"069eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Post-Modern Postcards","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"This Assessment Task uses the strategy of appropriation as a starting point to offer a technical and conceptual approach to the screenprinting process. Students are required to research an artist from any cultural or historical movement and select one work to use to inform your ideas in the production of a postcard. Do not directly plagiarise the work but alter it in some way to make a statement about this artist or use their work to inform your own. The imagery that is used can be interpreted, idealised, satirised or debased in a way so as to change the intent of the original work. The focus of this Assessment Task is on the content informing the prints, particularly in the strength of the development of the concept. Balancing this, students need to develop workshop skills including editioning (technical print quality and registration as well as image consistency between prints) and their studio work practice (quality of stencil making/exposure and clean work practices). Therefore a plan is essential for you to produce one double-sided image on a specified format. A short statement of no more than 250 words is required nominating the artist and artwork you have selected and explaining the rationale for your new and improved version of the artwork to be printed onto your postcard. Please address how you will be responding to both sides of the image. In this Assessment Task students will investigate and imaginatively interpret the concepts and conventions within screenprinting techniques by engaging with a structured exercise to explore the use of different materials and methodologies. In this Assessment Task students will establish verbal communication skills appropriate to their developing artistic practice and the processes encountered. Graduate Attributes: understanding of their discipline in its interdisciplinary context. capable of effective communication in expressing values, approaches and opinions in a variety of forms concerning their practice and the work of others.
Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) both individually during studio sessions and via group critiques at several stages before, during and after the execution of the project.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a9eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"969eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e69eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4e9eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Material Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"This Assessment Task encourages students to develop an artwork that responds to an environmental concern that is a result of human growth. Since the industrial revolution, the world has been developing at an ever increasing rate. Cities, buildings, bridges and roads have all become super-structures, thanks to a range of developments in building materials and techniques. Artists have traditionally drawn on the development of industrial materials and incorporated them into their process. How does the relationship between the material used in an artwork and the final outcome affect the reading of the work, and how can this connection be leveraged to add subtext to a piece? Student are asked to use printmaking techniques to create an artwork that draws part of its meaning from the dialogue between the material used and the images printed on it. Materials such as paper, metal, fabric, glass and plastic can be printed on, using an array of printmaking techniques, including screen-printing, digital print, lithography, photography and image release transfers. The final outcome will incorporate printmaking within another medium (sculpture, performance, video, installation, photo-media) to create a multi-disciplinary work that defies the expectations we have of traditional printmaking. In this Assessment Task students will investigate and begin to imaginatively interpret the concepts and conventions within screenprinting and other techniques by engaging with a structured exercise to explore the use of different materials and methodologies. In this Assessment Task students will establish verbal communication skills appropriate to their developing artistic practice and the processes encountered. Graduate Attributes: understanding of their discipline in its interdisciplinary context. capable of effective communication in expressing values, approaches and opinions in a variety of forms concerning their practice and the work of others.
Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) both individually during studio sessions and via group critiques at several stages before, during and after the execution of the project.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d29eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e69eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"969eb47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961957","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART2407.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2408 - Sculpture Performance & Installation: Experimental Fieldwork","description":"

This course introduces you to the value of fieldwork conducted outside the studio in urban and natural environments to enrich the content of your practice. In the process, you will build experiential and academic knowledge of the disciplines Sculpture, Performance and Installation Art and their interdisciplinary potential. The issues of identity, social engineering and indoctrination will be investigated in the urban environment. You will investigate environmental sustainability and our relationship to the natural environment and you will experiment with corporeal action, ephemeral processes, site specific installations and environmental interventions. Using your experiments and research skills in consultation with your lecturer and your peers, you will independently develop approaches to the representation of your ideas by fabricating a substantial body of artwork both in the studio and the natural environment. The principal aim is to build an integrated approach to art making supported by lectures, research, an intensive workshop, challenging project work and its critique. This 2nd Year course contributes to studies in the Sculpture, Performance and Installation stream.   


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b79ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Performance Workshop","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"Students demonstrate live the execution of performative actions, structures and processes that create an open framework on which multiple interpretations might hang, using the body as the expressive agency. Students' collaborative performances indicate an understanding and sensitivity to the manipulation of real time, duration, motion in space, pace, timing as an integral aspect of the structure of performance art. Students participate successfully in a collaboration as a creative strategy in performance art.
Students' explorative rehearsals are critiqued along with the outcomes of collaborative exercises, leading to the presentation of a performance in response to a brief. The performance is critiqued by the lecturer and peers, and a written summary of feedback is confidentially supplied along with a grading.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b9ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"239ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961961","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site Specific Research and Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"Students present an analytical critique of an artwork they have seen in an exhibition to learn to discern the artist's studio methodologies, for example aesthetics, the manipulation of encoded imagery, the articulation of elements of expression to achieve an investment of meaning in an artwork. This analytical process is applied to their own artworks fabricated in the field at Sculpture Camp in response to specific sites in the natural environment.
Seminar presentations are critiqued along with written reports and given a numerical grading of 20%. The work in the field is critiqued throughout the process of production and final presentation of the completed work in a group crit with the lecturer. The student receives confidential written feedback along with a grading.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b79ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f39ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6b9ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Camouflage Disguise","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"Students present their preliminary field research to the class for group discussion, and the completed artwork to the lecturer and their peers in as close to exhibition standard as circumstances allow. Students make an introductory statement of intent at assessment, as well as a project proposal to express their analysis of their approach to the project brief.
Fieldwork in the urban environment underlying this project is integral to the critical evaluation of the completed artwork. The student's art practice is critiqued throughout the process of production, including periodic peer revue. The completed work is analysed by the lecturer and peers in feedback at assessment, along with written feedback and a grading.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7b9ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b79ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f39ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a39ef47fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART2408.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
