This studio based course, SPI: Mixed Methods, begins with an exploration of articulated space, form and materiality to explore corporeal movement in stasis. The aim is to capture a feeling of action in abstract form derived from a collaborative movement workshop.  Using the traditional skills of carving and sheet metal manipulation in innovative ways, you will create an artwork that heightens your ability to visualise form in three dimensions, then execute this specific form using the precision of plaster carving. You will acquire the ability to make plaster casts and be inducted in advanced woodwork skills to make imaginative artworks that address stimulating conceptual themes.  You will exhibit artworks fabricated in this course  in a formal exhibition venue along with documentation of ephemeral, time based artworks created on the Sculpture Camp, where the skills you have learnt in class may be applied to environmental, site specific artworks. 

This course has a strong emphasis on vocational skills, and relates to companion courses in the Sculpture, Performance and Installation Stream by providing practical skills in association with other Sculpture Performance and Installation Year 2 courses in preparation for studies in 3rd Year. Your participation in peer feedback and collaborative activities contributes to the community of scholarship and creativity in the SPI Studio.

contentlets.keywords: art,woodwork skills,metalwork skills,casting,multimedia,object based art,conceptual projects,visual representation,site,spatiality,movement in stasis
contentlets.description:
This studio based course, SPI: Mixed Methods, begins with an exploration of articulated space, form and materiality to explore corporeal movement in stasis. The aim is to capture a feeling of action in abstract form derived from a collaborative movement workshop.  Using the traditional skills of carving and sheet metal manipulation in innovative ways, you will create an artwork that heightens your ability to visualise form in three dimensions, then execute this specific form using the precision of plaster carving. You will acquire the ability to make plaster casts and be inducted in advanced woodwork skills to make imaginative artworks that address stimulating conceptual themes.  You will exhibit artworks fabricated in this course  in a formal exhibition venue along with documentation of ephemeral, time based artworks created on the Sculpture Camp, where the skills you have learnt in class may be applied to environmental, site specific artworks. 

This course has a strong emphasis on vocational skills, and relates to companion courses in the Sculpture, Performance and Installation Stream by providing practical skills in association with other Sculpture Performance and Installation Year 2 courses in preparation for studies in 3rd Year. Your participation in peer feedback and collaborative activities contributes to the community of scholarship and creativity in the SPI Studio.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SART2411","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2411 - Sculpture Performance & Installation: Space Content Action","description":"

In this course, you will experiment with new methods of production, such as kinetic structures, digital technologies and their interface with innovative applications of traditional modes of production. The course encourages an integration of these technical fabrication skills with more informal approaches to studio production, such as the assemblage of manipulated found objects. You will research in depth your responses to a variety of interpretive project briefs that address the cross cultural and intrapersonal as well temporal phenomena, exploring improvisation, dynamic movement and action based art to expand your practice. The diversity of possible production methods and the conceptual content provides a diagnostic tool to determine the possible direction of your future practice. An active engagement in collaborative activities and discourse, rigorous feedback of work in progress, increases your ability to resolve your artworks' conceptual and perceptual coherence. This course relates to companion courses in the Sculpture Performance & Installation Stream by providing a mixed media skills base in association with other BFA Year 2 courses in preparation for studies in Year 3. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dcbeb87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Egg Shell and the Sword of Damocles","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

In the early 20th Century artist groups such as the Futurists and Russian Constructivists began to explore the creative and conceptual potential of machines and geometric structures as vehicles of expression. This experimentation continues in the 21st Century with the use of electronic devices, robotics, kinesthetics as important fields of contemporary visual arts. In the face of global warming these electro- responsive fields of practice have taken on new challanges ....

In response to these, and your own, contemporary challenges make an artwork that.

1/ Destructs

releases or moves antithetical or unlikely object(s): breaking, collapsing, or disseminating it in a predetermined manner. For example a fragile work placed in a precarious position or a kinetic work on a destructive trajectory.

Or

2. Protects

Protecting the object in the face of imminent threat posed by movement/change/time. For example, the object(s) could be disproportionately bulky, ephemeral, fragile, in comparison to the look &/or action of its mechanism, manipulator or projectile.

These works may, but need not be mechanical or electrical. In other words the potential present in the work may be implied.

Two high quality images need to be taken of the work presented (screenshots if video is used) and submitted to Moodle.

Submission details: 

·       Weeks 2-3 Present your idea with time line and budget in a consultation with your lecturer

·       Week 7 Present the work in a group crit before the class. Submit two high quality images to Moodle on day of presentation

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"80beb87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"84beb87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c0beb87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3aeb87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body work","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project will result in a physical performance, installation or three-dimensional work delivered before the class Week 12.

First, students will consider and interrupt accepted notions of the body. This task will require them to revisit what has been taken for granted or simply accepted as true in order to evaluate understanding of ‘body as a site’ of work. We will be looking in particular at the bodies relationship with space and matter, including people. 

Write a clear one paragraph artist’s proposal to clarify your ideas, inform your lecturer of your project’s conceptual and aesthetic objectives, and your plans for the process of production, including a timeline, and where / how it will be presented. In this project, the written proposal containing timeline and budget will be assessed for viability against the outcome. This document will also provide a basis for the analysis of each student’s methodology.

In exceptional circumstances students may work in pairs with their contributions each being individually assessed.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SART2412","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2412 - Drawing: Materials and Construction","description":"

Drawing: Materials and Construction invites you to explore various drawing methodologies as well as new and traditional processes of making drawing relating to contemporary aesthetics. The extension of drawing via concepts such as collage, assemblage, found object and new drawing mediums will be explored. With emphasis on the agency of drawing's immediacy and the physicality of materials, that is in context of how a drawing's content and form work together.


This course relates to companion courses in the drawing stream in that collectively they provide access to an ongoing studio experience. This drawing stream can also be done in association with other Year 2 courses in preparation for more advanced studies in Year 3.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"65bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Image and Object","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

The student produce a body of works about the perception of the object and process of image making. Each individual work/series of work should investigate the meaning of the object and the image, and the relationship between the object and the image.

This first project will consist of four drawing exercises that will make the content of the project. That is four drawings or four bodies of work that will comprise the the total project. Each week a new provocation will be introduced in class that will be handed in in week five.

Students will develop works that question whether the object is supporting the image or is the object represented by this image. 

The student is required to bring the art journal to class every week.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations. 

The student is obliged to document their process via moodle and by using the feedback loop of the Art journa

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2dbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"69bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"edbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Gesture and Trail","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In this project the finished work should demonstrate an understanding of the agency of drawing in relation to the Tom Waits song, “What’s he building there”. Students should consider the expressive potential of their chosen materials and the suggestive imagery of the song, i.e. how well does the materiality of drawing articulate the aims and intentions that are conjured in the song lyrics? 

Students should treat the song as an ‘object’, thinking about the potential of its visual form. Not as a list of things to be illustrated.

This project does not have to be seen as drawing in the traditional sense, it could also be performative in its outcome, as drawing is a performance in and of itself.

The student is required to bring the art journal to class every week.

Studio Practice requires at least 3 finished works (individual or in series) and the Journal. 

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations. The student is obliged to document their process via moodle and by using the feedback loop of the Art journal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2dbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"69bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"edbef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99bef87fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research File","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This project consists of editing,adding or applying drawing to an existing book (art journal). The journal must be considered as an artwork in itself and must comprise of at least 28 single pages or 14 double pages that occupy or edit an existing book (no blank pages), manual or journal. The journal can be pulled apart, reconfigured or changed in format. The art journal work should have coherence in itself, in that it should flow or the pages should relate to each other in either content or form.

The student will choose one element, sign or symbol that will be repeated on the pages to form a visual narrative that is poetic in its intentions.

The introduction to the project will be in week 5 but the final work presented in week 15 cannot be in the form of the original book, it must be transformed in some way.

The student is required to bring the art journal to class every week.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations. 

The student is obliged to document their process via Moodle and by using the feedback loop of the Art journal.

contentlets.description:
Drawing: Materials and Construction invites you to explore various drawing methodologies as well as new and traditional processes of making drawing relating to contemporary aesthetics. The extension of drawing via concepts such as collage, assemblage, found object and new drawing mediums will be explored. With emphasis on the agency of drawing's immediacy and the physicality of materials, that is in context of how a drawing's content and form work together.

This course relates to companion courses in the drawing stream in that collectively they provide access to an ongoing studio experience. This drawing stream can also be done in association with other Year 2 courses in preparation for more advanced studies in Year 3.
contentlets.title: Drawing: Materials and Construction

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2413 - Drawing and the individual","description":"

This is a studio based course that examines definitions and contexts related to the 'individual' through a series of practical projects. You will use drawing as an expressive medium to investigate figurative subjects in relation to culture, identity or technology. Your perception and representation of the individual in drawing practice will be actively challenged in response to such questions as, how do we understand the individual in a contemporary context?


This course relates to companion companion drawing courses that collectively provide access to an ongoing studio experience, and it is recommended that you will have undertaken other drawing courses before attempting this course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cfbe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961985","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Absence/Presence","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Approaching this assessment task as an expression of “non-conventional” portraiture, you will create at least three images of an individual that by-pass the literal mimetic tradition (i.e. an imitative representation of the real world). You will combine various modes and forms of figuration, semi-figuration, abstraction, and diagrammatic visualizations, and are encouraged to engage with diverse materials, technologies and experimental processes that position your artworks within an expanded field of drawing. The theme of “Absence/Presence” (as it pertains to an individual) should be understood in relation to similar concepts such as visible/invisible, explicit/implicit, and external/internal.

You might consider the relationship between subjectivity and objectivity in your investigations, as visual forms can be enriched, augmented by, or dependent on:

·     The subjectivity of human perception and analysis, conceptual interpretation, the imagination;

The objectivity of technological/mechanical processes and devices that monitor, measure, document and depict the body’s inner and outer states and structures. This might include the use of mechanical and digital reproduction technologies, and outputs from medical imaging and diagnostic tests, e.g. Radiography (the imaging of body structures using X- rays), Computed Tomography (CT) scans, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), electrocardiogram printouts, pathology tests (investigating functional, biochemical, nutritional, metabolic and hormonal states).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7abe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f2be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Between Private and Public","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Through the medium of drawing and its expanded practice, this assessment task explores the changing and increasingly indistinct boundaries between the private and the public. You might consider diverse visual themes and conceptual frameworks, including:

·     the examination of private and public personas (the way we ‘wear masks’ and modify our

·     performances or expressions to suit different audiences and circumstances);

·     self-disclosure and confessional art;

·     places and spaces that are private yet public;

·     illness and death in the public domain;

·     ‘peep’ culture;

·     the dissemination and exhibition of personal and erotic images;

·     technological interfaces, surveillance, data retention, and social networking sites that blur the line between what is confidential and publicly observed/transmitted.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7abe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b6be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6abe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Portrait Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Throughout the course, studio-intensive sessions will allow you to engage with various technical, experimental and material processes, and creative and aesthetic frameworks. These studio sessions will have as their theme the Self-Portrait: how do you see yourself as an individual; how can you explore, interpret, imagine, and represent yourself? You will undertake observational drawing and techniques that deliberately interrupt, subvert, and reshape your usual perceptual drawing processes; in effect, you will explore the ‘intermodality’ of drawing—the way your senses interact and intersect to provide you with a rich and complex experience of the world. Studio sessions will also allow you to use analogue and digital technologies associated with drawing, painting, photography, and transfer printmaking, collage, and montage that can position your work within an expanded field of practice. Exercises include kinesthetic drawing, naturalistic and proportional analysis, compositing images, temporal-spatial investigations, and collaborative drawing.

You will be required to present your ‘self-portraits’ in Week 12, to be assessed as a suite of individual works that represent diverse approaches, visual languages, styles, techniques, and materials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7abe3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b6be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2be3c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961973","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART2413.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2415 - Photographic Worlds: Interventions and Fictions","description":"

At what point do worlds and photographs collide to confuse perception, fabricate logic or create social tension? In this course you will explore the nature of photographic vision and the staging of ideas through the lens of medium format photography. In conjunction with these objectives you will develop your knowledge of location lighting, high-end scanning and a variety of output options to contextualise your concepts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"10ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961987","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Corners, Folds & Rabbit Holes","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This is task explores directorial photography in a contemporary context. It asks you to look specifically at how worlds are made and processed by simple interventions into spaces through the camera’s lens.

How do mountains become valleys? How corners become folds? Do all rabbit holes lead to Albuquerque? Think about how a simple sleight of hand or change in perspective can alter a terrain.

To undertake this assignment you will intervene into and transform a small part of an existing outdoor environment by using any materials at hand (including your camera). Photographically document this environment using varying available light and different perspectives (you can use whatever technology you have available - e.g. camera phone, compact or digital SLR camera etc). Consider what your understanding of the space is before and after you photograph your interventions.

For your final work, you will need to create one ‘straight’ shot of your environment (before your intervention) as well as a series of 5 photographs (hard copy, high quality photographic inkjet or chromogenic prints) which demonstrate how this environment has been transformed through your intervening and photographic actions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"14ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1cce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d4ce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0cce7c7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Staging Fictions","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Building on the outcomes of Assessment Task 1, you will produce a series of 6–8 photographs (at a scale(s) deemed appropriate to your conceptual intent) which explore specific elements of medium format photography and location lighting in relation to staged photography.

By developing and refining your intervention from the first assessment, you will further explore issues surrounding directorial modes of practice. Reflecting on the potential of the medium within this conceptual framework, you will use this knowledge to creatively consider and create a series of work which explores the medium's potential to stage fictions. The series may comprise exclusively of photographic prints or utilise expanded photographic outcomes aligned to the overall conceptual underpinnings/theme of your series.

contentlets.keywords: art,fine art photography,contemporary art,location lighting,directorial photography
contentlets.description: At what point do worlds and photographs collide to confuse perception, fabricate logic or create social tension? In this course you will explore the nature of photographic vision and the staging of ideas through the lens of medium format photography. In conjunction with these objectives you will develop your knowledge of location lighting, high-end scanning and a variety of output options to contextualise your concepts.
contentlets.title: Photographic Worlds: Interventions and Fictions

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2416 - Photogram to Instagram","description":"

Traditionally photography has been thought about as both an object of science and as way of scientifically observing the world. From photography's first light to the glowing screen of a phone you hold within the palm of your hand, we've longed to capture and possess life's invisible phenomena as well as its transient moments. This course explores the legacy of black and white experimental image-making processes using 35mm film and traditional darkroom techniques alongside their transformation within the context of new digital imaging technologies and social media platforms.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2417 - Photography and Shaping Light","description":"

Light can be the difference between materiality and immateriality – it's all in the way the shadows fall. This course develops your conceptual and technical knowledge of photography through an examination of micro and macro worlds constructed in the photographic studio environment. The course focuses on making the inanimate animate through the shaping of light. You will explore basic aspects of studio lighting and build your knowledge of different equipment and techniques, including electronic flash and tungsten lighting. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d3cefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961983","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Slow Light","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

In The Edge of Vision: The Rise of Abstraction in Photography Lyle Rexer writes that photography, by its nature “is an abstracting art involving a gap between what is seen and what is shown, regardless of the level of documentary fidelity” and that it is “simultaneously an investigation of reality and of the means of investigating that reality.” Abstraction and the loss of representational qualities in photography can be traced from the medium’s inception to current preoccupations and ideas that challenge the medium as essentially a process of recording or documenting a subject.

The photographic studio is conventionally thought of as a site into which one brings objects or subjects to photograph. However, this task requires you to produce a small body of related works comprising a minimum of four abstract photographs in which light appears to be the only evident subject. As a starting point for your ideas, draw on your responses to the contemporary artists’ works presented in the 'Slow light' lecture as well as on your own independent research into abstraction and constructed photography practices.

Use the tungsten light sources in the photographic studio and various light shaping, directing, reflecting, absorbing or mirroring devices to experiment with both harnessing light and controlling its absence in your photographs. Investigate the properties of light – reflection, refraction, dispersion, diffraction and interference – and consider how you can explore these for meaningful expression in a photographic form.

Your four photographs will be assessed as one body of related works.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"03cefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4fcefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36cefc7fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fast Light","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

What is the relationship of photography to its subject? How can the control of luminance partake in altering our perception of a subject or object? Construct a model of a micro (small -scale) or macro (large-scale) world of your choosing to bring to UNSW Art & Design Image Capture Labs. Working in your support groups in the Image Capture Labs and using electronic flash, over the next few weeks you will document your fabricated world to produce a set of five photographs that destabilise our expectations of photography’s relationship to its subject. As a starting point for your ideas, draw on your responses to the contemporary artists’ works presented in the 'Fast light' lecture as well as on your own independent research into constructed photography practices.

Consider the following technical concerns and how they can be deployed in your photographs successfully to alter our perception of a subject or object:

·       the appropriate scale for your constructed world (enlarged; 1:1 or miniature)

·       the quality of light (soft or hard; low or high key)

·       the quantity of light (depth-of-field and focus; blurry or sharp)

·       the use of reflectors or absorbers (fill or block light)

Your five photographs will be assessed as one body of related works.

contentlets.keywords: art,photographic lighting,studio lighting,photographic tableaux,photography still life,constructed photography
contentlets.description: Light can be the difference between materiality and immateriality – it's all in the way the shadows fall. This course develops your conceptual and technical knowledge of photography through an examination of micro and macro worlds constructed in the photographic studio environment. The course focuses on making the inanimate animate through the shaping of light. You will explore basic aspects of studio lighting and build your knowledge of different equipment and techniques, including electronic flash and tungsten lighting.
contentlets.title: Photography and Shaping Light

The aim of this course is to enable students to develop a command of painting as a visual arts discipline whilst consolidating and extending previously acquired painting skills and applying these to various aspects of life painting. Students will explore those aspects of life painting which will involve an examination of the clothed form, the nude or portraiture whilst providing opportunities to work from observational, interpretive and conceptual approaches.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2828 - Artists' Books","description":"

This Elective course will offer studio-based instruction involving class discussion and practical demonstration in a range of artists’ books through set projects that require an imaginative interpretation from the position of contemporary artistic practice. You will be assessed relative to your interpretation and realisation of 3 set projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to traditional and current art in book form.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"11de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Hard Cover Book Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will design and create a book object from several demonstrated options involving concertina, accordion and flag book forms with perhaps pamphlet-stitched sections. 

The concertina format offers great variety in both structural forms and intricate internal pages, offering an introduction to 3 dimensional design considerations. These elements will be demonstrated with an opportunity to make samples so that informed and critical descision making can be applied in the production of a cohesive outcome for this project. Pages and hard cover need to be securely joined and the completed work must be able to stand in an open state, displaying the internal pages, as well as to close, allowing the covers to protect the internal pages. Technical competence is crucial in the realisation of this work and must be clearly demonstrated.

 • Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• Interim feedback in Week 5 and prior to Assessment in Week 15

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"15de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"99de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Hard Cover Longstitch Book Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will create a book object based on a demonstrated hinged structure with multi sections stitched through the spine section. 

This book introduces a hinged hard cover structure with the potential for it to develop into a hinged box form. It will contain multiple but independently stitched sections of, if required, papers of varying thicknesses. The flexibility of this structure allows for pages to contain pockets, fold-outs and pop-ups or other bulky material. The exposed spine stitching offers further design possibilities, which should be explored. This book is to demonstrate exactness in the creation of secure hinges that flex and creates ease of movement. It requires careful designing before construction as the exact size and thickness of the exposed hardcover is determined by the fianl thickness of the internal pages. Cover edges, corners and lining must display a high degree of finish, and should form part of a wholisticly presented artist's book. This book form is very suitable for the display of artworks such as prints as it opens flat. Sections may be removed and alternate sections stitched in without disturbing the remaining sections.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• During the presentations of Project Proposals.

• Prior to Assessment in Week 15.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"15de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5dde30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"99de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d5de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"85de30bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Soft Cover Book Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will create a book object based on side stitched or stab binding techniques.    

A technically simple structure that will offer the key elements in the understanding of the Artist's Book form. These will include intergrated cover and internal page design and the management of tactile and time based factors through the linking of sequential imagery and text ideas.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• During Assessment in Week 5.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"SART2829 - Anatomy for Artists","description":"

This course will provide an introduction to human anatomy primarily through the study of surface form and skeletal and muscular structures. Emphasis will be placed on direct observation of the nude model, the écorché model, skeleton, casts and prepared anatomical specimens. A range of approaches will be included to encourage students to understand basic anatomical constructs and drawing. Perspectives on historical and contemporary anatomical art will provide students with a platform for developing their own investigations and creative responses.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dffdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Skeletal Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

The aim of the assessment task is to introduce you to individual bones, the complete skeleton, joints and articulation, and ‘bony landmarks’ as an expression of an inner skeletal framework. You will be presented with reference material enabling you to understand and render anatomical proportion, structure, and form. Various concepts and analytical strategies will be proposed including direct observation and palpation. Studies will be made from the skeleton and the life model, and will include detailed drawings, mass conceptualizations, and skeletal ‘overlays’. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"87fdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97fdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b6fdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Muscular and Musculoskeletal Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

The aim of the assessment task is to introduce you to the muscular system (largely 1st layer and 2nd layer muscles and tendons that impact on the surface form of the human figure), the muscles’ relationships to the skeleton, and general surface landmarks of the body. Mass conceptualized, naturalistic, and ‘overlay’ drawings will be undertaken primarily from the nude model and the écorché, supported by the study of the skeleton, anatomical specimens, and plaster casts. Various analytical strategies will be used including direct observation from the life-model, self-palpation, self-observation, and the conceptualization of form via anatomical photos and illustrations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"87fdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97fdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cffdc577dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Anatomical Self-Portrait","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This project requires you to creatively interpret the anatomical subject, integrating observational drawing with anatomical knowledge and perspectives on historical and contemporary anatomical art, self-portraiture, nude portraiture, and figure drawing. Through this synthesis, you will establish an individual approach to subject, narrative, theme, and employ an appropriate visual language, style, technique(s), and materials. The discipline of anatomy will be configured, conceptualized, and elevated into the arena of personal interpretation and expression.

You will produce a naturalistic (i.e. figurative, representational) Self-Portrait as—and/or with—an anatomical subject. You will reference the face/figure/anatomical form from ‘the life’ as well as photographs and other visual, illustrative sources. There are many possible structural, compositional, aesthetic, and expressive permutations for delineating and ideating the figure, and many possible anatomical (skeletal and muscular, flayed, dissected, exploded) conventions, frameworks or references to be made.

For inspiration you should research historical and contemporary images of human anatomy in medicine, art, and design. Personal exploration and research into the field of anatomical art may be complemented by visits to the Australian Museum, the Anatomy Museum, Kensington UNSW, or other appropriate institutions. Investigations may be extended and your subject inspired by any of the sciences (comparative anatomy, evolutionary biology, medical imaging, natural history, etc.) or the arts and culture (history, philosophy, psychology, literature). In this regard, you might locate the artwork within personal, cultural, and scientific frameworks, engaging with the psychological, medical, political, moral, philosophical, spiritual, sexual, social, and art-historical, for instance.

This project is self-directed and will be undertaken outside of your timetabled/scheduled class. For assessment purposes it will be supported by an 'Artist’s Statement'. The statement will require: (i) a title of the artwork; (ii) the media, e.g. ink, charcoal, and acrylic on paper; and (iii) a description of the artwork that explains your concept (150 words).

Materials: any drawing medium or associated practices within the expanded field of drawing (collage, painting, sculpture, digital media, mixed media). Size: approx. A0 (double A1), though the paper size and shape may be determined by compositional requirements or aesthetic/conceptual choices.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART2836 - Colour","description":"

This course will investigate the theory and practice of colour as it applies to the discipline of painting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fe314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Colour as Material","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

“Colour is mysterious, eluding definition; it is a subjective experience, a cerebral sensation depending on three related and essential factors: light, an object, and an observer.”1 Unlike colour, paint is a physical substance that requires empirical (experiential) knowledge—for the painter, colour is material. With this in mind, you will be introduced to the pigment properties of paint such as transparency/opacity, lightfastness, and tinting strength. This assessment task focuses on developing your understanding of colour mixing using rigorous analysis and experimentation through trial and error. Students will complete a traditional colour wheel focusing on tonal value using a ‘split primary’ system as an introduction to the materiality of colour. A series of experiments will also be undertaken using application techniques such as flat (opaque), transparent, and ‘broken’ colour to explore how paint can be manipulated to achieve different colour effects and qualities. The experiments should culminate in a garden landscape painting (A4 size) employing the application techniques listed above. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aa314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b6314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e6314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Hue, Value, Chroma","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment task begins with a comprehensive lecture introducing colour space. This lecture will be elaborated in class with further information aimed at enhancing your knowledge of the colour attributes of hue, value, and chroma. You will develop your understanding of these attributes and your ability to modulate paint colour in relation to hue, value and chroma through practical exercises in the studio. Students will complete a painting on a primed 16x20” (40x50cm) canvas board of a scene that includes two glossy spheres, one white and one uniformly coloured, as well as an ‘invented’ object, e.g. a cube, resting on a light grey surface. Lighting on the scene and all objects within it must appear consistent and the painting should demonstrate effective paint handling. Students will also undertake several experiments that explore colour relationships using the framework of hue, value and chroma. These experiments are to be submitted in a folder/portfolio for assessment along with the 16x20” (40x50cm) painting of 3 objects. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6a314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f2314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a314537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Colour Composition","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment task requires you to transcribe and respond to a detail of a painting on display at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. You will select a painting from the period 18th-20thC and document a detail of it using a 10 x 10cm grey ‘window frame’ and camera. Consider the variety of imagery and paint qualities possible within this frame; your selected detail could be more or less ‘abstract’ depending on the stylistic approach and scale of your chosen painting, and positioning of your frame. You will take notes in situ at the AGNSW that describe the palette, texture, transparency/opacity of paint etc. to assist you with your research. In the studio, you will be required to match the colour qualities and application techniques of the painting detail by making a small transcription to scale i.e. 10x10cm (reflecting the dimensions of the window frame). Students will be required to produce a second painting (40x40cm) based on the detail, employing the same palette as the transcription, but inventively interpreting colour proportion, mark-making and application techniques.

The theory of metal casting will be discussed as it applies to individual work required by the student.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3400 - Painting in the Expanded Field","description":"

Painting in the Expanded Field will encourage you to develop an individually conceived art practice that explores materials, processes, technologies and formats which can contribute to a broader understanding of painting as a discipline. Questions of interest include, What constitutes painting? How might an understanding of painting as a medium, material, process, object, concept or discourse be meaningfully expanded through an engagement with other disciplines such as photography, sculpture, installation, design, craft and digital media? To what extent can an interaction with everyday life and 'non-painting' take place and still relate to painting?


Painting in the Expanded Field is an advanced Year 3 studio course within the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. It is one of a suite of interrelated core Painting courses that comprise a four-course specialisation in the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. This specialist course covers professional studio knowledge, skills and attitudes for painting. This course builds upon concepts and methodologies introduced in Year 2 Painting courses, and relates to companion Year 3 Painting courses by providing a context for more advanced and self-directed studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e3deb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will write a 300 word Project Proposal outlining the aims and approaches for their major project. The proposal concept will emerge from studio investigations and should contextualise the project within contemporary fields of expanded painting, offering comparisons with other contemporary artists. 

Students will be required to ‘pitch’ a well-researched proposal in a short verbal presentation (max 3 mins) to class peers and engage in a group discussion in Week 6. The pitch should stake out a claim for the planned major project and developing independent practice.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) and peers via group critiques and/or consultations. Students are to document the feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7deb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"97deb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The Major Project is the main assessment for this course. The aim of the major project is to develop skills in approaching and producing rigorous, self-directed practice-led research.

Students will produce a resolved body of work that extends from a sustained inquiry into the expanded field of painting. The final body of work and supporting material should evidence a thoroughly researched, conceptually driven and independent approach. Students should build on the skills and knowledge gained through the experimental investigations in the first part of the semester.

Things to consider are:

  • What methods and processes are adapted from the painting studio as they expand across disciplinary boundaries?
  • What constitutes painting?
  • To what extent can interaction with everyday life and “non-painting” take place and still relate to painting?

The major project should be accompanied by the final written project proposal that situates the student’s work within historical, cultural, scholarly and contemporary contexts articulating concerns and issues related to painting in the expanded field.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) and peers via group critiques and/or consultations over the course of semester. Students are to document the feedback. Feedback for this assessment task is provided through Review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5fdeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"abdeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dfdeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Collaborative Studio Investigations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

 In response to weekly themes, students will work collaboratively in Research Clusters to explore how painting as a medium, process, object, concept or discourse can be meaningfully expanded. Research Clusters of up to 6 students will discuss and respond through studio practice to questions and propositions raised at the end of class lectures. Students will also conduct further research (outside of class) into contemporary / expanded painting practice and related conceptual, historical and contemporary fields of knowledge. Students should guide their investigations, studio experiments and discussions around their own interests and intentions for their major projects. Research Clusters will set up and present their portfolio of work in the studio in Week 5. Each group will have a maximum of 10 minutes to briefly explain how they have responded through practice-based methods to the research questions. Emphasis should be on discussing the physical paintings, objects, installations or models in the portfolio.

Feedback is provided by lecturer and peers via group critiques and/or consultations. Students are to document the feedback.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3401 - Painting Futures Studio","description":"

Painting Futures Studio will enable you to develop an individually conceived art practice that explores speculative propositions and tests new ideas. You will be required to address how creative concepts inform the future. You will investigate questions such as, What insight can be gained from the history of painting and how can it provide a context for the future? What are the realities of the present that point toward the next age? In response you will be asked to identify areas of research in relation to a consideration of future. Areas of interest might include utopias and dystopias, posthumanism, evolution, science fiction, scientific discovery, parallel worlds, virtuality, and ecological prospects. This will help you to better appreciate the extent to which painting can offer a way to think about the future.


Painting Futures is an advanced Year 3 studio course within the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. It is one of a suite of interrelated core Painting courses that comprise a four-course specialisation in the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. This specialist course covers professional studio knowledge, skills and attitudes for painting. This course builds upon concepts and methodologies introduced in Year 2 Painting courses, and relates to companion Year 3 Painting courses by providing a context for more advanced and self-directed studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"58eeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Experiment Dossier","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

For this assessment students are to present their initial experiments, prototypes and visualisations for their major research project (Assessment 2). Students are to produce 5 experiments that test a variety of approaches to your chosen research question. The research questions are listed in the Assessment Section on Moodle. Choose one of these. These experiments are important stages of practice-led research and should be developed alongside other forms of research (for instance considering theory, science, material investigations, technology, ecology, sociology, politics etc.).

This assessment functions as an early reflection point for the development of the final research project. It condenses brainstorming, speculation and conceptualising into a present moment for the purposes of critique and critical peer-review. 

Informal/formative feedback: In-class discussions will be held in the lead up to and the week of submission. This will include advice and general feedback.

Formal/summative feedback: Your work will be marked by your lecturer and written feedback will be provided along with a grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"08eeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"44eeb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73deb0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Research Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"65","description":"

Students will respond to one of the set research questions (list on Moodle). Working in research clusters students will experiment, research and reflect on what the questions means, and how they can respond as a painter. Students will use practice-led research (a mode of research that takes making as a way of working through problems and generating new ideas) to develop and refine a response.

Students are to produce a work (or body of works) that is refined, engaging and critical. It must reflect an appropriate amount of scholarship for a major assessment. There are no size or medium restrictions—large scale, virtual, speculative works should be discussed with your lecturer for the most appropriate mode of presentation or documentation. Works will be presented in the 3rd year studio space unless otherwise organised with the lecturer.

Students are to submit a 250-word abstract with their work that summarizes the approach they took to answer the question and what their results were. Students are to upload this to Moodle with your Group Work Report (explained below). A copy of the abstract should also be printed and placed next to the work.

Students will submit a PDF Group Work Report on Moodle. This report is to be structured into weekly entries, (6 in total) of 200 words per entry. Each entry will discuss what students learnt from sharing ideas and resources with other students and reflect on how this contributed to developing your research project. Students can also discuss how they contributed to other student’s projects. Students will be assessed on demonstrating a commitment to sharing of research and ideas and their reflection on the process of collaborative studio practice.

Formal/summative feedback: You will be formally assessed by your lecturer and written feedback will be given.

contentlets.description:
Painting Futures Studio will enable you to develop an individually conceived art practice that explores speculative propositions and tests new ideas. You will be required to address how creative concepts inform the future. You will investigate questions such as, What insight can be gained from the history of painting and how can it provide a context for the future? What are the realities of the present that point toward the next age? In response you will be asked to identify areas of research in relation to a consideration of future. Areas of interest might include utopias and dystopias, posthumanism, evolution, science fiction, scientific discovery, parallel worlds, virtuality, and ecological prospects. This will help you to better appreciate the extent to which painting can offer a way to think about the future.

Painting Futures is an advanced Year 3 studio course within the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. It is one of a suite of interrelated core Painting courses that comprise a four-course specialisation in the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. This specialist course covers professional studio knowledge, skills and attitudes for painting. This course builds upon concepts and methodologies introduced in Year 2 Painting courses, and relates to companion Year 3 Painting courses by providing a context for more advanced and self-directed studies.
contentlets.title: Painting Futures Studio

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3402 - Painting: Studio in Context","description":"

This course allows you to concentrate on your major creative direction as an artist. You will be required to research your chosen area of interest and initiate a body of studio work informed by the relationship between your own practice-based research, contemporary art practice and inter-disciplinary methodologies. The course assists you to extend and develop the focus of your inquiry towards a coherent body of work, building upon the theories and concepts that have emerged in your course of study. You will be encouraged to evaluate and articulate the relationship between your proposed intentions and the outcomes achieved in your studio practice.


Painting: Studio in Context is an advanced Year 3 studio course within the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. It is one of a suite of interrelated core Painting courses that comprise a four-course specialisation in the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. This specialist course covers professional studio knowledge, skills and attitudes for painting. This course builds upon concepts and methodologies introduced in Year 2 Painting courses, and relates to companion Year 3 Painting courses by providing a context for more advanced and self-directed studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f9eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Establishing Topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment task 1 aims to develop key terms and concepts that locate an individual student’s studio practice. This task will clarify your aims and intentions and provide a foundation for writing a project proposal. You should think about the things that motivate your work (for example politics, the environment, identity or other artists) and find the appropriate terms and concepts that relate these general motivations to your developing studio practice.

You will workshop key terms and concepts over weeks 1-3 alongside studio based practical research, supported by research into other artists working with similar ideas, processes and materials. This information (key terms and concepts, aims and intentions of practice, and research into other artists) will be entered into a work-flow form for submission at the end of week 3. At this stage, you must have evidence of studio experimentation and works in progress that demonstrate an awareness of your terms and concepts. Over the remainder of semester, you will use this form as a guide to locate your developing practice in a structured relationship to contemporary art and ideas.

A template work- flow form will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"65eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1deef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This task is a written proposal for a body of work that positions your developing relationship with the studio within a set of theoretical, formal and conceptual parameters. It includes but is not limited to - what the work means, how it is made, how many components it has and what the relationship of these parts is to the whole. The proposal should elaborate a timeline, include a title and establish the links between the body of work and contemporary art and ideas.

Since a body of work is the outcome of experimentation, research and development in the studio, evidence of practice-led research and work-in-progress should accompany the proposal. These two components - the body of work in theory and practice - will be reviewed together as part of the mid-semester review process.

The written proposal should be limited to 1 page (max 500 words) and submitted in week 5. In addition, you will summarise your proposal verbally in class (max 5 mins) in front of your studio work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"65eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65eef0bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body of Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

In assessment tasks 1 and 2, students locate their practice in relation to contemporary art and ideas by linking it to key terms, concepts and other artists researched. In developing a proposal, students cultivate their aims, intentions, and understanding of these terms with regards to studio practice. Over the course of the semester, students are required to plan and produce a body of work that reflects their understanding of the concepts and processes engaged through studio practice. Assessment task 3 is the presentation of this body of work.

The body of work, comprising a number of individual elements (to be discussed with lecturer depending on scale, materials and conceptual rationale), must be accompanied by a wall label clearly stating name and student number, title of the work/s, materials and processes. Students are responsible for sourcing all equipment required to install their body of work and to ensure that it is presented professionally.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3403 - Painting: Studio Practice","description":"

Painting: Studio Practice requires you to undertake advanced research and experimentation with mediums and processes contextualised by contemporary painting practice and your individual research priorities. You will further explore methodologies through studio-based investigation and critical reflection. Studio activities will develop your project proposal into finished works, in consultation and using guidance offered in class tutorial sessions. You will receive the critical support needed to pursue practice-led research methodologies in relation to contemporary painting. Building from previous studies in the other Painting courses, Painting: Studio Practice will lead to develop the basis for a more committed and focused body of research suitable for further development in the Honours year.


Painting: Studio Practice is an advanced Year 3 studio course within the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. It is one of a suite of interrelated core Painting courses that comprise a four-course specialisation in the BFA(Hons) or BMA(Hons) program. This specialist course covers professional studio knowledge, skills and attitudes for painting. This course builds upon concepts and methodologies introduced in Year 2 Painting courses, and relates to companion Year 3 Painting courses by providing a context for more advanced and self-directed studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0bee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Theme and variation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment Task 1 requires you to produce a body of work consisting of a minimum of eighteen A4 paintings featuring a recurring motif that undergoes a series of translations through your studio processes. Your chosen motif may be anything you determine to be of sufficient visual and conceptual interest (an everyday object, a photograph, an artwork from history, etc.). You are to explore multiple possibilities for interpretation across your series of images, using a rich diversity of materials and techniques. The aim is to develop a practice-based research methodology for your individual studio practice, and explore the formation of meaning through making and critical reflection.

Your work is to be displayed in class for assessment, accompanied by a three-minute verbal presentation summarizing your concept and approach. The task must also be documented in a professional manner with good quality photographs, including captions and notes that record your experimentation with materials and techniques, and your level of participation in the course (your written notes need not be more than approx. 300 words in total but should include evidence of your own critical reflection in response to feedback in class). The documentation should be compiled as a research portfolio and uploaded to Moodle as a PDF on the day of assessment.

Your series of eighteen works should demonstrate a commitment to your chosen motif (as opposed to indecision and inconsistency). Consider Claes Oldenburg's statement ‘I am for an Art’ (1961), which lists a vast range of possibilities for art, demonstrating that the impetus for an artist’s practice can come from anywhere. He writes:

“I am for Kool art, 7UP art, Pepsi art, Sunshine art, 39 cents art, 15 cents art, Vatronol art, Dro-bomb art, Vam art, Menthol art, L&M art, Ex-lax art, Venida art, Heaven Hill art, Pamryl art, San-o-med art, Rx art, 9.99 art, Now art, New art, How art, Fire Sale art, Last Chance art, Only art, Diamond art, Tomorrow art, Franks art, Ducks art, Meat-o-rama art.”

[Extract from Claes Oldenburg, "I Am For an Art...” in Environments, Situations, Spaces(New York: Martha Jackson Gallery, 1961); reprinted in an expanded version in Oldenburg and Emmett Williams, eds.,Store Days: Documents from The Store (1961) and Ray Gun Theatre (1962)(New York: Something Else Press, 1967), 39-42.]

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47ee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"83ee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cfee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7aee34bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Assessment Task 2 requires you to produce a self-directed body of work situated in relation to contemporary painting practice. The aim is to develop a cohesive and committed studio practice through material investigation, conceptual development, and contextual research, assisted by discussion and critiques in class, individual reflection.  

You are to produce a portfolio of studio work consisting of at least one experiment per week over Weeks 5-10 (minimum 6 experiments in total), plus a highly resolved major work which may consist of a large-scale piece (minimum dimension 120 cm), or multiple resolved works of a smaller scale. Your experiments should consist of material investigations relevant to the development of your major work, and your work should directly respond to the studio and the discoveries that are made within that specific site.

You must also prepare a statement of 300 words (maximum) addressing your work’s concept, methodology and contextualisation. All work for this task must be displayed for assessment and professionally documented in a PDF uploaded to Moodle by the due date.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3404 - Printmaking: Expanded Fields","description":"

Printmaking: Expanded Fields offers a balance between concept and process-based instruction involving lecture, individual and group critiques, and relevant technical demonstrations that will further an awareness of the place and diversity of the print in the field of contemporary art. Through individually managed projects, fostering the establishment of a research base, you will have access to the full range of printmaking methods and be encouraged to combine them or incorporate other fine art processes in your developing practice. Assessment will involve 1 set project and 2 self-directed projects using a working proposal that articulates the scope of your creative interests and a plan for its realisation. 

This 3rd year studio course contributes to one of two, four-course specialist Printmaking 'streams'. It builds upon the knowledge and skills generated in the SART2404, SART2405 stream, along with other stream and elective courses, to establish a technical and conceptual framework for the SART3405 Printmaking: Independent Studio Practice course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"64fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961980","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This Assessment Task requires students to declare their research and working intensions for a Self-Directed Project that demonstrates a speculative consideration of the form of the artworks that will be attempted. The underlying concept and technical possibilities relating to the work that will be attempted must be discussed and developed in consultation with the lecturer and recorded in a typed Project Proposal of no fewer than 500 words to be submitted by Week 6. Students are to participate in a powerpoint presentation session were the concepts and research generated for their submitted artwork is discussed and reviewed by the lecturer and their peers. Lasting no longer than 5 minutes, it must indicate the core issues guiding the production of the artwork attempted and reference a considered response to 2 artists that inform your thinking. These presentations will be conducted during the 2nd half of the Semester.

  • Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 
  • During the presentations of Project Proposals during Weeks 9 to 13.
  • During Group Critique sessions scheduled for Weeks 11 and 12.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"68fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ecfe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: State your Business: Making Prints in an Expanded Field","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task requires each student to declare their interests and for this personal perspective to form the starting point for an image. The production of an artwork that can constitute a form that incorporates any combination of print mediums or a synthesis with methods beyond the realm of the reproducible. In response to lectures, discussions, readings and studio experiments introduced during the first half of the course students will work towards their final outcome with the benefit of critique sessions and peer review. Regular reports on the project development will be given, beginning with an initial statement in Week 2, which will build through conceptual and technical acquisition until its assessment in Week 6.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

During Critique session in Week 4.

• During Assessment in Week 6.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2cfe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"90fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"90fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2:Search, Visit, Look and Put","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This Assessment Task requires an analysis of print related theory, material and practice within your chosen field via an introduction to the research facilities available in the AGNSW Study Room. There is an expectation that students will expand upon their knowledge of historical issues with particular emphasis on those that continue to inform current conceptual philosophies and technical approaches for the development of research skills to assist in the foundation of an individual studio practice. 

Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions.

During presentations at the AGNSW in Week 5.
