Printmaking: Independent Studio Practice offers an in-depth engagement with the diverse methodology and creative strategies of printmaking and how that corresponds with the ideas that inform contemporary professional art practice. Through individually conceived and managed projects, reinforcing a developing research base, you will access the full range of printmaking media and be encouraged to combine them or incorporate other fine art processes in your evolving practice. Assessment will constitute 1 set project and 2 self-directed projects using a working proposal that articulates the focus of your creative interests and a plan for its realisation and exhibition.

This advanced 3rd year studio course contributes to one of two, four-course specialist Printmaking 'streams'. It is the culmination of the knowledge and skills generated in the SART2404, SART2405 stream in 2nd year and the research framework established in the SART3404 course.




","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"95fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Self-Directed Research - Part A","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task, Self-Directed Research – Part A, requires the submission of a body of work that reflects 6 weeks of production and will contribute 30% towards the final assessment mark. This presentation of work should reflect the intensions stated in the proposal presented and submitted for Assessment Task 1 ‘Meet the Press’. Depending upon the context and format of the work, each image is to be accompanied by a wall note that clearly states: name; student number; title of the work; dimensions, media used and an artist’s statement of no fewer than 250 words. It is the responsibility of students to find an appropriate neutral space if they want to make an installation of the completed work.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given weekly through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• During Assessment in Week 8.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"09fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c9fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"05fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Meet the Press","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This Assessment Task has two parts in a written proposal and a powerpoint presentation involving a clear presentation of intentions for the body of work to be submitted for the Mid Semester Assessment. Students are to announce and succinctly identify the key issues in a proposal of no less than 500 words along with an oral and visual presentation as a 10minute ‘Press Conference’.

  • Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions.
  • During the presentation session in Week 2
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"09fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"55fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b0fe74bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Self-Directed Research – Part B","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The Part B of the Self-Directed Research proposal is the opportunity to present considered reflection of your self-directed research at the halfway stage of the semester and should clearly demonstrate a development upon the preparatory work produced in the Part A component in Assessment Task 2. Students are asked to re-align the aims and objectives of their proposal after the Assessment process in Week 6 and as a consequence they can change or develop their ideas and approach. The Part B component should show evidence of development in your concepts and a clear understanding of how to focus the outcomes of Part A into a coherent and expansive plan for a body of work, that also demonstrates progression of your practice in a technical capacity. This will involve the resubmission of your proposal clarifying your plans in a 500-word document in Week 8.  At the assessment event in Week 15 each image is to be accompanied by a wall note that clearly states: name; student number; title of the work; dimensions, media used and an artist’s statement of no fewer than 250 words. It is the responsibility of students to find an appropriate neutral space if they want to make an installation of the completed work.

  • Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions.
  •  During the Assessment process in Week 15

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3406 - Printmaking: Media and the Message","description":"

Printmaking: Media and the Message is a Level 3 course which furthers your awareness of the roles and diversity of the printmaking as a media of contemporary art practice.  The course addresses both development of concepts and development of process.  It uses lectures, individual and group critiques, and relevant technical demonstrations to support your individually managed projects, and foster the establishment of a base for research.  The course will support your development as an artist through access to the full range of printmaking methods and offer encouragement to combine them or incorporate other fine art processes in your developing practice.  

Assessment will involve 1 set project and 2 self-directed projects based on your working proposal that articulates the scope of your creative interests and a plan for its realisation.

This 3rd year studio course contributes to one of two, four-course specialist Printmaking 'streams'. It builds upon the knowledge and skills generated in the Level 2 courses, to establish a technical and conceptual framework for the development towards an independent printmaking practice.



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2937a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will produce a body of artwork that reflects the work proposal submitted in Week 7. Students are not required to edition this work but it should be submitted, if relevant, in a state that is flat, clean and signed in pencil using the universally accepted conventions for unique state prints (instruction will be offered relative to signing protocols).

This assessment is a culmination of the work undertaken in the course over the semester and should show evidence of development in each student’s concept and a clear understanding of how to focus the outcomes of Assessment Tasks 1 and 2 into a coherent and expansive body of work. Students will have the opportunity to re-align the objectives of their work proposal after the assessment process in Week 7 and as a consequence there is the possibility to change or develop their ideas and technical approach.

Students will continue to develop verbal communication skills appropriate to their evolving artistic practice and the processes encountered during individual consultation with the lecturer or in group critiques.

A wall caption for the completed work should accompany its presentation. This component will form 5% of your final mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2d37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1537a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This Assessment Task focuses upon creating an awareness of your place in the diversity of contemporary print- based art practice. It requires each student to articulate their interests, positioning their studio project within a set of theoretical, formal and conceptual parameters that have been defined in art discourse. This is expected of practitioners in the fine art industry and a normal process when seeking representation or when pursuing further study. A proposal defines your interests. It is the starting point for a process where fundamental questions are asked. What do I want to make art about and what does it mean? How will it be made? What are its component parts, and what will the relationship of these parts be to the whole?

For this task you will produce a presentation accompanied by a 600 word proposal describing the work that will be undertaken for the final project (Assessment Task 3). A draft of the proposal is due in Week 2, and feedback will be provided.

Students will be developing their studio based work for Assessment Task 2 concurrently and studio based processes will inform the project proposal. Assessment Task 2 outcomes will be presented in class the same week as Assessment task 1 presentations occur.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ed37a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9137a5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimentation and Investigation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment requires the submission of a substantial body of work that reflects 6 weeks of production and will contribute 30% towards the final assessment mark. This independent studio practice should relate to the intensions stated in the draft work proposal discussed with the lecturer and in the presentation of Assessment Task 1. It is important that the work produced fully explores the scope and potential of the ideas developed and that evidence of experimentation is present. A continued process of skills acquisition is crucial to achieving the best outcomes for the assessment event at the conclusion of the term, so it is suggested that the ideas developed dictate the use of a process that is best suited to represent them.

You can use any of the mediums encountered in your studies, or in the Makers Space, and must ensure that you have read and signed off on the Safe Working Procedures listed on the UNSW SafeSys site. The draft working proposal submitted may indicate the need for technical or process instruction that can be supplied or organised by the lecturer, which can be scheduled during the first 6 weeks of term.

You will continue to develop verbal communication skills appropriate to your evolving artistic practice and the processes encountered during individual consultation with the lecturer, student presentations or in group critiques.

contentlets.description:
Printmaking: Media and the Message is a Level 3 course which furthers your awareness of the roles and diversity of the printmaking as a media of contemporary art practice.  The course addresses both development of concepts and development of process.  It uses lectures, individual and group critiques, and relevant technical demonstrations to support your individually managed projects, and foster the establishment of a base for research.  The course will support your development as an artist through access to the full range of printmaking methods and offer encouragement to combine them or incorporate other fine art processes in your developing practice.  

Assessment will involve 1 set project and 2 self-directed projects based on your working proposal that articulates the scope of your creative interests and a plan for its realisation.

This 3rd year studio course contributes to one of two, four-course specialist Printmaking 'streams'. It builds upon the knowledge and skills generated in the Level 2 courses, to establish a technical and conceptual framework for the development towards an independent printmaking practice.
contentlets.title: Printmaking: Media and the Message

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3408 - SPI: The Public Domain","description":"

This specialist course teaches professional studio management and vocational strategies in the Sculpture Performance & Installation Studio. You learn how to effectively respond to a public art commission, identify the Visual Arts research field in which your art practice is located in preparation for Honours, and produce self initiated artworks for formal public exhibition, including the documentation of ephemeral works. This project work  prepares you for a vocation in the Visual Arts industry. You will devise a hypothetical public art commission, do the fieldwork of an appropriately selected site, plan and produce a proposal for formal submission to an acting commissioning panel.


This enquiry deepens your understanding of where your practice is located in the fields of research associated with contemporary art practice, a key aspect of studio research in Honours. Self initiated artworks are produced in consultation with your lecturer, including site specific works, environmental works, at the Sculpture Camp, which is associated with the Faculty of Art & Design's Environmental Research Initiative for Art (ERIA), located in SPI.


You will also focus on accurate documentation as a vital skill for exhibiting representations of your ephemeral artworks. Your artworks will be formally exhibited with attention to conventions surrounding exhibitions, such as writing an artist's statement of intent for a catalogue. On-going feedback, analysis and assessment of works, your leadership and contributions to the community of scholarship and creativity in SPI contributes the process of induction into a vocation in Fine Arts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cafeb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Public Art Research and Lineage","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Student's research and analyse their own Art Lineage in relation to exhibition within Public Space.

Students are to choose artworks which interest them in relation to a public art project, politics and spatial intelligence.

Assessment, including feedback, is a keystone in the learning process.  

Informal feedback, including evaluations of your ideas and work in progress in tutorials and group crits to assist with decision-making throughout the project are invaluable sources of inspiration, direction and knowledge. 

The ability to assess one’s own ideas and decisions is an attribute of all successful artists and is encouraged in the studio with the support of your lecturer.

At assessment your peers and lecturer will verbally critique the work.

Your lecturer will give you a written summary of this feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"75feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Model Phase for Public Artwork","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Student's produce drawings, models and performances which document their initial ideas. Models can be physical or virtual. The models at this stage conceptual and thus are rudimentary and assisted by verbal presentation and research images from the internet.

Informal feedback, including evaluations of your ideas and work in progress in tutorials and group crits to assist with decision making throughout the project are invaluable sources of inspiration, direction and knowledge. 

The ability to assess one’s own ideas and decisions is an attribute of all successful artists and is encouraged in the studio with the support of your lecturer.

At assessment your peers and lecturer will verbally critique the work.

Your lecturer will give you a written summary of this feedback and a written critique of your written project work.

Assessment Task 3

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"75feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Public Art Commission Proposal + Associated Artworks","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Ultimately this project is about the translation of student work and artistic interests to a different scale and outside the gallery.

In this final stage of a public art project students are both experimenting with their practice, but also stepping into politics. Public space is political. The final work proposal is not necessarily full size, although it could be, but rather a way of communicating an idea to a system of approvals and bureaucracy. This does not necessarily mean capitulation to outside forces. If Ai Wei Wei can fill a gallery with millions of ceramic sun flower seeds - why can't you? Convince us or simply do it in public.

Assessment, including feedback, is a keystone in the learning process.  

Informal feedback, including evaluations of your ideas and work in progress in tutorials and group crits to assist with decision making throughout the project are invaluable sources of inspiration, direction and knowledge. 

The ability to assess one’s own ideas and decisions is an attribute of all successful artists and is encouraged in the studio with the support of your lecturer.

During formal assessments your peers and lecturer will verbally critique your artwork.

Your lecturer will give you a written summary of this feedback and a written critique of your written project work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"75feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1feb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cefeb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdfeb4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART3408.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SART3409","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3409 - SPI: Self Initiated Work","description":"

This studio based course teaches Sculpture, Performance, and Installation Art in all its cross disciplinary, cross cultural guises. The aim is to produce a self motivated practice resulting in a substantial body of major artworks. Conceived and executed under your own aegis, you will  make artworks,  with the guidance of your lecturer, building on your experience of the many approaches, conceptual frameworks and open experimentation experienced in previous studio courses, and your studies of the theory and history of Contemporary Art Practice. Exploratory experimentation is underpinned by a rigorous attention to your aesthetic and conceptual objectives, your methods of material execution, whether action based or ephemeral. With an emphasis on progressing your independent practice, the course supports your imminent transition to the rigour of studies in Honours, and from art student to contributor to the wider arts community and a vocation in the arts industry. The course aims to equip you with management skills to facilitate this transition, reinforced by feedback, tutorials. skills acquisition tailored to the requirements of your self initiated practice.  For SPI's studio theory program, Talkfest, you will reflect upon your development to analyse and define the particular proclivities of your practice, beginning the initial stages of planning  a research proposal for your Honours Year. At this level of study your participation in critical discourse, outreach and collaborative activities provides valuable leadership in SPI's community of scholarship and creativity. 



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9ffef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Test works","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Via a process of experimentation with concepts, methods/techniques and materials, develop 2-4 test works that extend the ideas and interests expressed in the Map of Artistic Practice that you will develop for Week 3 (as a non-assessed activity). The test works should begin to explore the concepts and forms that you will develop in your final project.

You will present your test works in a verbal presentation to the class (maximum 5 minutes + 5 minutes Q&A). You should describe what you have done and what you are aiming to achieve physically and conceptually. Pay particular attention to summarising how your artistic practice connects with the artists included in your Artistic Map from Week 3.

On the day of assessment, you will:

  • Present the project work in class (maximum 5 minutes + 5 minute Q&A) in a group crit.
  • Upload at least one image of each test work to Moodle after class.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1bfef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"57fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dbfef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4ffef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Finished artwork","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

You should edit and develop your test works from Week 7, incorporating previous feedback, scaling up your ambition and aims for the project outcomes, and adding new approaches where relevant, to produce a final artwork. This should resolve the physical, conceptual and technical challenges that you set yourself moving on from the test works. In a verbal presentation to the class, you should describe what you have done, explain the ideas involved and evaluate the outcomes.

On the day of assessment, you will:

  • Present the project work in class (5 minutes + short Q&A) in a group crit.
  • Upload at least one image of your final work to Moodle after class.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1bfef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"57fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"93fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"87fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART3409.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3410 - SPI: Relational Art","description":"

This course focuses on art practices that are positioned in social contexts and that place the viewer or community at the centre as agent rather than the autonomous artist. This course provides you with the opportunity to explore this interdisciplinary, interactive way of working with social issues and community in mind. You will begin with the initial stimulation of a concept based project, considering the ramifications of locating artworks in the context of an outdoor urban development. The course enables you to develop a largely self-directed project that addresses an appropriate topic in consultation with your lecturer. This specialist course investigates professional studio practice, the deployment of appropriate methodologies, such as learning skill sets appropriate to your creative tasks, and requires a self motivated committment to your practice in the Sculpture Performance & Installation Stream. In particular, you will learn to address issues usually outside the provence of gallery based art, with consideration of engaging interactive participants rather than passive viewers. This course relates to companion courses in the Sculpture Performance & Installation Stream by providing opportunities to extend your practice to include interactive art in association with other Sculpture Performance & Installation (SPI) courses in Year 3.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cc0ff4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Beyond the White Cube","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

During the last 40 years, and particularly over the last 10, there has been a movement away from the gallery as a repository for art and a point of exchange for aesthetic based ideas.

With this in mind, students will be required to commit to an exhibition in a 'remote' public urban site in Randwick. Using skills developed during the sculpture camp (semester 1) they will create site-specific interventions, performances, installations, and sound and light works. They will be asked to react aesthetically to site, whilst also dealing with the myriad technical and compliance issues that accompany the creation and installation of publicly sited work. They will also be encouraged to work in public to progress the exhibition, and this will in itself become a performative act, or at very least an act of public communication.

The exhibition is to be formally opened in September by a Randwick Council dignatory, and viewed by thousands of attendees of Randwick Eco Fair

  • Feedback will be given one-on-one as the projects take shape.
  • A class crit will be held after the exhibition de-install, back in class. Each student will present their 'findings' in this crit/project wrap-up.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0c0ff4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"37fef4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Self-Initiated White Cube Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are asked to first assess what lessons they have learnt from working on Project 1 in a public space, then consider whether, and how, these can be applied to the 'white cube'. They are asked to consider this controlled 'white' space, and construct a work that functions within a specific 'artist run space', whilst still managing to relate to a community outside that control. 

Work will be exhibited in Airspace Gallery, Marrickville, and an opening held, in November.

  • Feedback will be given one-on-one as the projects take shape.
  • The projects themselves will be assessed whilst on exhibition, taking into account relationships to both the space and the other works.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3411 - SPI: Studio Research","description":"

The principal aim of this course, SPI: Studio Research, is to support the exploratory research underpinning your  production of a substantial body of experimental artworks for public exhibition. The aim is to enhance your ability to creatively integrate context, research, processes and technology to invest meaning. Assessment in this course rests upon the formal presentation of artworks, of a standard appropriate to this level of study, that are underpinned by an imaginative exploration of ideas, their conceptual contexts and methods.  


SPI: Studio Research is an investigative course dedicated to expanding as well as refining your art practice.  Your lecturer will teach you practical skills and the value of research methods, both academic and practical, and how to apply them to optimise the depth and quality of your Sculpture, Performance and Installation Art. In the process, you will strive to resolve your ideas to create coherent self determined artefacts. Self motivation and sustained effort is required. This course correlates with companion courses in the Sculpture, Performance and Installation Stream, combining to intergrate a successful completion of your BFA studies in Year 3 in preparation for Honours.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"700f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation of work-in-progress","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

You are required to present your work-in-progress in an environment that mimics an open studio suitable for a curator's visit. This presentation of your work should demonstrate your studio activities and research to date. It may involve a combination of preparatory work, experiments, models and maquettes as well as visual content to highlight reference points and influences.

During class, you must present your work-in progress (6-7 mins) in the context of your open studio to your peers and lecturer. This will prompt a short critical discussion around your works in progress, providing feedback that informs the development of your work. Feedback may engage you in directional shifts, comment on contexts to locate your works and draw attention to ethical issues that may be present.

You will be assessed on the rigour and quality of your studio-based research/work to date and your capacity to reflect critically upon your processes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"240f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"600f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"140ff4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

You should present your final work/series of works to a professional standard of production. Your work should resolve the main research areas that you set yourself and demonstrate your capacity to engage rigorously with contemporary art studio practice. You will present your work individually in class in a structured verbal presentation (6-7 mins) that evalutes the work with reference to your initial Research Proposal (Assessment 1).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"240f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"600f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"640f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c0ff4bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You should submit a research proposal (maximum 500 words) outlining a set of studio research activities that you will undertake during across the course of the semester. These activities will guide your art-making and inquiries and lead to a completed work/set of works that demonstrates awareness of the role of form, content and context.

In this proposal you must attempt to position your practice-led research within broader cultural, philosophical and social contexts. You should identify appropriate methods and forms of creative exploration to guide and sustain your self-directed creative explorations.

Within this proposal you should address:

1. Thematic concerns: key areas of inquiry, primary sources and conceptual interests.

2. The contexts relevant to your studio research: This may include references to a combination of historical, personal, social, environmental, cultural or artistic contexts that inform your studio processes. This may include artistic movements, artists and other cultural producers working in a specific field both historically and in the present.

3. Materials, methods and processes: This may include outlining forms and avenues of studio experimentation, technologies and techniques and ways of gathering data and information to guide your practice.

4. Planning, production and realisation: This should include a feasible timeline outlining any risks or factors that need consideration as well as addressing issues around fabrication and labour. Bear in mind, practice-led studio research involves experimentation, structured and non-linear processes with unforeseeable outcomes.

Submission details:  

Submit your draft proposal to Moodle by Monday of Week 3.

Make a verbal presentation of your Research Proposal in class (4 mins). This will be followed by verbal feedback from peers and the lecturer. 

Submit your final Research Proposal in Week 4.

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SART3412","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3412 - Experimental Drawing","description":"

The ‘Experimental Drawing’ course is designed to introduce the experience of creatively exploring experimental materials, processes, methods and ideas in contemporary drawing practice. Particular emphasis is given to drawing as discovery, testing and its expanding vocabulary, its signs and symbols, its gestures and marks, its pigments, supports and tools, and developing a range of new skills by working with different subjects, processes, tools and media. 


You will be encouraged to develop an individually conceived art practice that experiments with materials, processes, technologies and formats that can contribute to a broadened understanding of drawing as a discipline. Individual projects will seek to explore what drawing is and does across a range of disciplines and over a broad historical period. Extensive experimentation in problem solving through individual exploration is emphasized.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9a0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961915","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Research Cluster Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Weekly lectures and themes will introduce contemporary artists working with experimental drawing mediums, concepts and processes. Research Questions will be discussed at the end of each lecture and will be linked to the experimental methods discovered in the lectures and weekly materials. Research Clusters of up to 6 students will respond to the research questions through studio practice, discussing ideas raised in class lectures, readings, videos and other course materials. These responses should be experimental and may take the form of drawings, diagrams, models, performances, networks or objects.

Research Clusters will set up and present their portfolio of work in the studio in Week 6. Students should show physical drawings, objects, experimental demonstrations or installations etc. The portfolio may include a mix of larger collaborative and smaller individual responses; however there should be clear evidence of group discussion and a considered curation of the portfolio as a whole.

Each group will have a maximum of 10 minutes to briefly explain which research questions they have responded to and show how their experiments have addressed those questions. Groups can choose to prioritise one of the topic areas from Weeks 2-5, so long as they have evidence of some experimentation from each week. Again, the focus of the presentation is on demonstrating that questions and propositions are being explored through studio practice.

Groups are also required to submit a PDF of images and text (300 words max) that provides a synopsis of aims, concepts and methods of their weekly studio experimentation and contextualises concepts and issues relating to experimental drawing with research into relevant contemporary artists. 

  • Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) and peers via group critiques and/or consultations. Students are to document the verbal feedback throughout semester.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4e0f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d0f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Studio Portfolio Process","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will engage in independent practice led research in the studio weeks 7-14. Students may extend earlier experimentation undertaken for Assessment 1 and should guide their investigations and studio work around their interests and intentions for their Major Projects.

As a result of this experimentation students will produce a portfolio of studio process work. The range of studio investigations will directly respond to issues related to drawing in contemporary practice. The investigations should be experimental and may take the form of drawings, diagrams, models, performances, networks, installations or objects. The emphasis is not on polished, refined works, but on demonstrating that questions and propositions are being tested through studio practice.

Portfolios should contain written summaries of concepts and methods to contextualise the studio process work within fields of experimental drawing, offering comparisons with other contemporary artists. Portfolios can be submitted in the form of a process diary or folio but students are encouraged to discuss alternative creative forms of showing process work with class lecturers.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations. Students are to document the feedback over the course of semester.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4e0f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8a0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b50f38bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The Major Project is the main assessment for this course. The aim of the major project is to develop skills in approaching and producing rigorous, self-directed practice-led research. Students will plan, develop and produce a resolved and self-directed body of work that extends from a sustained inquiry into drawing in contemporary practice. The final body of work should evidence a thoroughly researched, conceptually driven and independent approach.

Feedback is provided by lecturer(s) via group critiques and/or consultations throughout semster. Students are to document the verbal feedback. Feedback on assessment tasks is available through Review.

contentlets.description:
The ‘Experimental Drawing’ course is designed to introduce the experience of creatively exploring experimental materials, processes, methods and ideas in contemporary drawing practice. Particular emphasis is given to drawing as discovery, testing and its expanding vocabulary, its signs and symbols, its gestures and marks, its pigments, supports and tools, and developing a range of new skills by working with different subjects, processes, tools and media. 

You will be encouraged to develop an individually conceived art practice that experiments with materials, processes, technologies and formats that can contribute to a broadened understanding of drawing as a discipline. Individual projects will seek to explore what drawing is and does across a range of disciplines and over a broad historical period. Extensive experimentation in problem solving through individual exploration is emphasized.
contentlets.title: Experimental Drawing

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3413 - Drawing: Studio practice","description":"

SART3413 Drawing: Studio Practice is an advanced drawing course. It enables you to further develop your studio skills and insights in drawing through a major project. The course provides a critical and constructive opportunity for you to select and focus on areas of personal creative interests and work to refine your ideas, whilst identifying and resolving problems in your practice.


You are required to develop a project proposal, which will focus on clearly defined avenues of interest within Drawing practice, with scope for potentially exploring a cross-disciplinary approach. You will be required to research your chosen area(s) and complete a coherent body of practical work that demonstrates the relationship between your work and contemporary art and/or media practices in the field.


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0b0f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing Lineage and Linkage","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

his project links your interests in drawing studio practice with the possibility of a cross disciplinary approach.

By researching the art historical lineage of your drawing and art making, in parallel with key interests in other disciplines, you will understand the unique role that the studio has as a 'site' for generating ideas and diagrams of linkage.

The final outcomes will include text, and a number of prototypes "idea drawings", which start to make cross-disciplinary bridges possible within your evolving studio practice. You will be drawing a suite of images which represent the mapping of a visual problem and a possible series of solutions to these problems. These images also locate your studio practice within contemporary art practice.

Terms that apply to the making of this work would include frottage, stencil, collage, layering, text, cartoons, realism, diagrams, digital, punk and alternative media.

This work will be the 'machine' or 'engine' that drives the final drawing suite handed in in week 12.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"760f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b20f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"660f78bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Drawing Suite","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The final drawing suite can now take a 'form' that reflects the previous research into your artistic lineage and cross-disciplinary experimentation. In other words this assessment demonstrates an outcome or formula that derives from the Lineage and Linkage project .

The final form can be drawing in the traditional sense or alternative in that it could be performance based, sculptural or digital as long as it shows a relationship with the Lineage and Linkage project.

The final outcome must be a substantial collection of drawing that equates to a term's worth of work.

This self initiated project will enable you to identify the areas of practice and research to establish a transition to 4th year honours.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3414 - Photography: Place and the Everyday","description":"

What experiences and traces of history shape our knowledge and perceptions of place? How can photography explore and inform our concepts of natural landscapes and urban environments? This course introduces you to the relationships between memory, place and the everyday through the photographic practices of site-specific research, archival exploration and storytelling. Alongside working with your own camera equipment, you will be introduced to field cameras and large format photography while exploring a range of traditional and expanded photographic responses to a specific location.

contentlets.description: What experiences and traces of history shape our knowledge and perceptions of place? How can photography explore and inform our concepts of natural landscapes and urban environments? This course introduces you to the relationships between memory, place and the everyday through the photographic practices of site-specific research, archival exploration and storytelling. Alongside working with your own camera equipment, you will be introduced to field cameras and large format photography while exploring a range of traditional and expanded photographic responses to a specific location.
contentlets.title: Photography: Place and the Everyday

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3415 - Photography: Independent Studies","description":"

This course provides the opportunity for you to further advance and refine your research, methodologies, and practical skills into an emerging art practice. Its focus is on your development of a self-directed body of photographic or related work that draws on your skills, research and informed knowledge in the context of current contemporary art discourses. The course also draws on current exhibitions, artists, theories and critical debates to assist in the development, production and contextual framing of your self-directed project. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3d1ff8bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961931","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project (Work-in-Progress)","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

During the semester, you will create and refine a body of self-directed work. You are expected to begin exploratory research and experimental making at the outset of the semester, developing your work further over the course in consultation with your lecturer. You are also expected to maintain a visual diary of your own developments/experimental processes and related influences, which will provide continuity to your work and experiences. Please ensure that you bring this with you to feedback sessions and reviews/assessments.

As a guide, your self-directed project should be developed with attention to:

1.     Content/subject matter

2.     Production method and processes (including the work’s materiality and how it is viewed or installed)

The work presented for your final submission should exhibit a high level of the synthesis of content and form, a refinement of technical skills and an awareness of installation contexts.

Assessment Task 1 requires you to produce a self-directed, experimental body of work- in- progress for class critique and discussion. As a starting point for your ideas, draw on your responses to and analysis of the concepts and works presented in the Contemporary Art and Photography I lecture as well as on your own independent research into current art practices and concerns. Your work-inprogress installation for the class review should evidence your research; evidence the critical development of your concepts; and evidence your working methodologies for your self-directed inquiry as outlined in the points below. Regardless of the medium used, you should aim for a body of work-inprogress that is equivalent to approximately 8 – 10 images.

Your installation for the in-class review should include:

1.     Contact proofs and/or work prints

2.     A selection of edited photographs that have been printed or output to different scales and onto different material supports (i.e. technical experimentations) and/or

3.     A selection of digital files and/or moving images output to data projections or to monitors; sculptural and/or 3D objects; paintings; printmaking, etc

4.     Relevant visual support material (e.g. evidence of the research undertaken, including contextual research of related artists’ works, ideas and philosophies that have influenced your work)

5.     Propositions for the refinement and resolution of your work for the end of semester (e.g. drawings, maquettes or other visualisations, etc)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a51ff8bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f11ff8bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"291ff8bfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961901","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project (Final Submission)","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"55","description":"

Building on the parameters and frameworks established in Task 1, Assessment Task 2 requires you to refine your semester work-in-progress to present a well-developed body of photographic and/or related media work. Your final submission should demonstrate evidence of the formal refinement of ideas, materials and technical skills since the work-in-progress assessment.

As a means of identifying how to refine your ideas and improve on your technical skills, draw on your responses to and analysis of the concepts and works presented in the Contemporary Art and Photography II lecture as well as on your own independent research into current art practices and concerns.

Your installation for the in-class review should include:

1.     A refined body of photographic and/or related media (e.g. moving image, painting, sculpture, printmaking, etc) work that is equivalent to approximately 8 – 10 images. The refinement of work is evidenced by your decisions regarding the editing of the work; the scale of the work; material supports for the work; and projection/display devices for the work; and the installation of the work

2.     Relevant support material (e.g. your visual diary that includes evidence of the research undertaken, including contextual research of related artists’ works, ideas and philosophies that have influenced your work)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3416 - Photography: Public and Private","description":"

In a media-saturated world photography is often a driving force in how we navigate, record and make sense of the spaces we travel through and inhabit. In this course you will explore the idea of photography as both a medium and way of seeing in the 21st century. You will focus on photography as production and uses within real and virtual public spheres and how this defines and shapes our perceptions of geography, identity and politics. From 'selfies' to Google street-view and surveillance, you will explore everyday processes of photographic materiality, transmission and circulation in contemporary art and life using readily available tools and mediums, such as Xerox-imaging, camera-phones, social media and agitprop poster practices.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3417 - Photographies: Expanded Fields","description":"

What is photography? Taking this deceptively simple question as the starting point for its investigations, this course introduces you to expanded definitions, experimental processes and hybrid forms of contemporary photography. Through an investigation of contemporary photography as an interdisciplinary art practice you will explore a variety of experimental outcomes, which consider the medium's potential as moving image, sculpture, installation, performance, drawing, painting and writing. The emphasis will be on extending the skills of your primary practice through conceptual strategies and varied frameworks of photography. The course also examines the work of contemporary artists within this context to assist in the conceptual and practical development of your work. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"331f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Hybrid Images","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Today’s photographic practitioners are responding to shifts in contemporary image-culture by working with diverse ideas, processes and materials. For them, the photographic image is no longer a static container of meaning, but instead, a hybrid and fluid form that can enmesh with other materials and mediums to explore the diversity of how we encounter and understand the world around us.

For this assessment task, you will create a small work that explores the hybridity of the photographic image. Your work will take one (or more) of the photographic qualities that have been identified and discussed within class as its starting point, and investigate the diffusion of photography across a variety of conventions, materials and technologies. In undertaking this task, you are encouraged to consider where the boundaries of the photographic image lay, and where photography might blur into other forms and mediums.

Your work should be installed and/or displayed in a format that enhances the work’s aims and concepts. Your work is due at the beginning of class in week 4. You should upload your work (or an indicative image) to Moodle prior to class. 

You will then present your work in class, where you are expected to introduce your work and describe how it is situated in the context of previous class discussions about ‘hybrid images’. The purpose of this presentation is to allow for informal feedback about your work from the class. You will be assessed on the quality of your work according to the criteria below, rather than on what you say about it. In developing your work, you should carefully consider any ethical implications, undertake safe work practices, and act according to standards appropriate to UNSW.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"371f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f71f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f1f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Artist Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This course charts the way that photographic practitioners explore the diverse potentials of image making in a contemporary context. It is crucial that when engaging with this field, we develop understandings of the complex ways that artists experiment with ideas, forms and processes. To this end, art history and theory provide key tools that help us to better understand and discuss artistic strategies and their intersections with broader historical, social and cultural debates. Understanding these relationships between theory and practice are also crucial for developing an informed and self-sustaining independent practice. Researching other artists and reading about their works and contexts are fundamental skills in developing your own creative approaches.

For this assessment task, you will conduct a 10-minute oral presentation in class. Your presentation will draw on the particular week’s set reading in order to discuss your selected artist (from the list provided). Your presentation is expected to use the following structure:

1.     Briefly introduce the artist

2.     Briefly introduce the reading

3.     Identify 3 key points from the reading

4.     Visually analyse a single work in detail

5.     Make connections between the reading and the artwork

Your presentation should be supported by a visual aid (e.g. a PowerPoint presentation) that also includes a bibliography of references at the end. You will be required to upload your visual aid to Moodle prior to the class in which you present your analysis.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f1f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb1f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a71f3cbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Expanded work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This task requires you to develop a new body of creative work that explores the potentials of photography in and as an expanded field of practice. The focus of this task is to develop and enhance your self-directed practice. You should therefore carefully consider how your work gives form to the motivations, compulsions and drives of your specific practice in the contexts of expanded photography as developed throughout the semester. The outcomes and formats of this task are open-ended, and should be appropriate to your formal, conceptual and process-based interests. You should build on the forms, processes and concepts from Assessments 1 and 2, and consider process as much as end product.

Your work should be installed and/or displayed in a format that enhances the work’s aims and concepts. Your work is due at the beginning of class in week 11. You should upload your work (or an indicative image) to Moodle prior to class. You will then present your work in class, where you are expected to introduce your work and describe how it is situated in the context of previous class discussions about ‘expanded photography’. The purpose of this presentation is to allow for informal feedback about your work from the class. You will be assessed on the quality of your work according to the criteria below, rather than on what you say about it.

In developing your work, you should carefully consider any ethical implications, undertake safe work practices, and act according to standards appropriate to UNSW.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3703 - Walking as Art","description":"

Walking as Art focuses on the long but little known history of art that engages with walking, as a practice of the artist and as a way of encountering communities and landscapes.  In this course, you will research the use of walking or journeying in modern and contemporary art practice, and develop your own art project in the context of a walking experience.


You will engage with both the urban and natural environment while exploring how the experience of walking transforms perceptions of the environment. The course will allow you to create an itinerant community art project from the material of walking through an environment. You will work in teams to create and present a body of art work for exhibition.


Walking As Art is taught intensively over two weeks, and is often held overseas. Students may need to allow for airfares and accommodation costs and should contact the Faculty for more details.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Writing","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Following the walking component of the course, students will write a 1000 word reflective summary of their experience that also explores how they relate the ideas explored to their own practice.    


A combination of written and verbal feedback will be given

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4310537db391c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f210537db391c50eb6b147a3a961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will work together in teams to create then install a public art work in the field


The Lecturer will assess the creative response in relation to the Course Aims. Students will then engage in Peer Assessment to ensure equity in relation to the contribution of each team member

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f210537db391c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a7210537db391c50eb6b147a3a961936","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exhibition of individual work","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be assessed on how well they can translate a lived experience into a body of work for exhibition.Discussion will be held on how the reflective piece of writing can be translated into a research project that results in a body of work for exhibition

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Individual feedback will be given on a continual basis, starting with discussions on the piece of reflective writing and how this can become a research project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb210537db391c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ef210537db391c50eb6b147a3a96193a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART3703.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Walking as Art focuses on the long but little known history of art that engages with walking, as a practice of the artist and as a way of encountering communities and landscapes.  In this course, you will research the use of walking or journeying in modern and contemporary art practice, and develop your own art project in the context of a walking experience.

You will engage with both the urban and natural environment while exploring how the experience of walking transforms perceptions of the environment. The course will allow you to create an itinerant community art project from the material of walking through an environment. You will work in teams to create and present a body of art work for exhibition.

Walking As Art is taught intensively over two weeks, and is often held overseas. Students may need to allow for airfares and accommodation costs and should contact the Faculty for more details.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART3800 - Professional Practice","description":"

This course provides you with a range of skills that prepare you for working as an artist or culture maker. The course focuses on developing effective strategies and knowledge with which to navigate the complex terrain of the arts and cultural sectors. The course addresses key aspects of professional practice such as communication, collaboration, community, marketing, working with institutions, ethics, and money.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dd610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Cultural Engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Taking into consideration your planning and tutor feedback from Assessment 1 you will:

  1. Select, meet and report on a discussion with a mentor on the development of your creative practice ?
  2. Select, attend and review a public event that is significant to the development of your creative practice ?
  3. Design and implement a strategy for situating your practice within the public sphere - this is to be discussed with your tutor - but could include creating the introduction for a website, writing a draft application for a grant or exhibition, hosting an event, creating a blog, creating a professional CV and so forth. ?

Rationale: Recognizing the diversity and complexity of cultural practices that make up the art world students will develop their own pathways for nurturing their practice into the professional realm. ?

Expectations: Students will write an 500-800 word report that details how they achieved the 3 tasks set for this piece of assessment and evaluating the impact this has had on their professional development. You should attach screen shots, web-links or other documentation of your work. ??

Submission details:

Via Moodle

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Students will receive written feedback from their tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"19610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c9610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation and Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

You will work together in groups to research and present information on one of the topics listed below. Your 20min presentation should be aimed at providing practical information for emerging artists including examples of best practice and resources for further information and support. Your presentation should be prepared as a group but can be presented by a single representative. Information sheets, web-links and practical examples are encouraged. Your presentation will be followed by a tutorial discussion on how the information presented relates your individual creative pathways. Group members are encouraged to outline how the information presented impacts on their own creative pathways to provide examples for the class.

Topics to choose from:

  1. Insurance for Artists: what are the issues, what support is out there for artists
  2. Appropriation, Copyright and Moral Rights for Artists
  3. How to curate an exhibition (selecting from your tutes artists statements curate a mock exhibition detailing all the steps needed to take the exhibition from concept to reality)
  4. How to negotiate working with the creative materials of others (detail key issues to think about such as ethics, release forms, collaborations, contracts, agreements, collectives)
  5. Getting paid for your art – taxation, ABN, invoicing, awards, rates, unions, internships. What issues do artists face, what support can they look for?
  6. What it takes to do a good application: verbal pitches, written applications, informal approaches, presentations, where to find out about grants and opportunities.

Submission details:

Presentation in class.

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Students will receive written feedback from their tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"55610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"85610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Creative Practice Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment summary:

  1. You will write a brief (200 word) report on your current practice and plan three steps you could take to develop it further. This plan should include specific ideas for how to develop your creative practice such as galleries you plan to approach for exhibition opportunities, mentors you wish to meet, further training you might need to take, internships, grants or applications you hope to apply for and so on. This plan, and the feedback you receive on it, will form the basis for Assessment 2, so aim for outcomes that are useful, achievable and interesting.
  2. You will write a brief (100 words) biography of your current practice. Please outline your creative practice and any key achievements. This bio must be written in the third person and be available to circulate publicly on Moodle.
  3. You will write a brief (200 word) description of your most significant creative work. This description must be accompanied by 1-3 images with captions be formatted on one A4 PDF and available to circulate publicly on Moodle.

Submission details:

Via Moodle.

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Students will receive written and verbal feedback from their tutor.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9001 - Studio Concepts and Practices","description":"

Studio Concepts and Practices is designed to provide you with an understanding of the ideas, concepts and material processes that inform the environment in which studio based contemporary art is researched, developed and produced. It is a studio-based course which develops the conceptual, technical and material foundations essential to contemporary creative self-expression.  


The course introduces the formal language and terminology of contemporary ideas as they apply to the making and context of contemporary art.  It facilitates an understanding of the technical properties specific to different forms of creative expression across various media and demonstrates how studio concepts and methodologies shape approaches to the construction of meaning in contemporary studio based practices.  


The course is taught in the studio through a system of lectures and practical studios and tutorials.

Studio Concepts and Practices is designed to provide you with an understanding of the ideas, concepts and material processes that inform the environment in which studio based contemporary art is researched, developed and produced. It is a studio-based course which develops the conceptual, technical and material foundations essential to contemporary creative self-expression.  

The course introduces the formal language and terminology of contemporary ideas as they apply to the making and context of contemporary art.  It facilitates an understanding of the technical properties specific to different forms of creative expression across various media and demonstrates how studio concepts and methodologies shape approaches to the construction of meaning in contemporary studio based practices.  

The course is taught in the studio through a system of lectures and practical studios and tutorials.

Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9002 - Process and Materiality","description":"


Process and Materiality provides an interdisciplinary studio based environment for students wishing to enhance their understanding of the role materials and processes play in contemporary fine arts practices. It is designed to support your ability to plan and present works of art that evidence how processes and materials contribute to meaning-making. You will explore significant processes as you develop a studio methodology for your work. You will examine materiality as an integral component of the agency of a work of art and as an index of potential content. You will be encouraged to link materiality, process and technology with both historical and contemporary perspectives to realise self directed studio outcomes.


Process and Materiality builds on the foundations laid by SART9001: Studio Concepts and Practices or equivalent in equipping you to ground your practice in an understanding of the vital role played by process and materiality in the development of a sustainable studio methodology and the development of a professional artist practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a4610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"One Thing Leads to Another: Part 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Use at least five different means of fixing and fastening to make a non-figurative work composed of five different materials.

Start a portfolio, which will be a key repository for all visual and graphic material developed in the preparation, planning and realisation of this semester's work.

Presentation in group critique week 3. Photographic documentation to be submitted through Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"68610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1061c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"One Thing Leads to Another: Part 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Combine soft, hard, natural, synthetic, granular, powdered and liquid substances in one work.

Investigate how these materials behave and misbehave by examining their material properties, are they elastic, rigid, viscous, manufactured or raw? Will they oppose or accommodate each other?   Engage these materials in experimental ways testing their capacity for combination and potential deployment in the making of an artwork. Resolve as a maquette, working model, discrete object or installation scenario.  

Presentation in group critique week 8. Photographic documentation of work to be submitted through Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"68610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a4610d37db391c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5861c937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"One Thing Leads to Another: Part 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Plan, develop and complete a self-initiated work that includes one component from each of the previous two assignments. The work should demonstrate an awareness of process and material character as being significant factors in the development and composition of an artwork. 

Presented for group critique in Week 14. Photographic documentation to be submitted through Moodle.

contentlets.description:
Process and Materiality provides an interdisciplinary studio based environment for students wishing to enhance their understanding of the role materials and processes play in contemporary fine arts practices. It is designed to support your ability to plan and present works of art that evidence how processes and materials contribute to meaning-making. You will explore significant processes as you develop a studio methodology for your work. You will examine materiality as an integral component of the agency of a work of art and as an index of potential content. You will be encouraged to link materiality, process and technology with both historical and contemporary perspectives to realise self directed studio outcomes.

Process and Materiality builds on the foundations laid by SART9001: Studio Concepts and Practices or equivalent in equipping you to ground your practice in an understanding of the vital role played by process and materiality in the development of a sustainable studio methodology and the development of a professional artist practice.
contentlets.title: Process and Materiality
