Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9003 - The Consolidated Studio","description":"


The Consolidated Studio is designed to develop your understanding of trans-disciplinary modes of visual authorship and their relationship to the expanded field of contemporary creative expression. It supports the development of practice based research and topic lead enquiry. You will be challenged to locate your developing practice within a framework informed by media plurality and conceptual rigour. This course provides an opportunity to consolidate your practical and conceptual skills through the production of a resolved body of work supported by expert guidance and consultation as well as peer feedback. You will be introduced to concepts and strategies which inform contemporary practice and develop processes to engage and contribute to these fields. The course prepares you to undertake and complete the major capstone project in the final semester.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1b018df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work Proposal and Presentation before the class","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are asked to develop and present a proposal of work to be undertaken. Students should include artistic influences; underlying ideas in their practice and the anticipated resolution of the final work(s) and also outline the viability of the intended work; a budget and a timeline to installation.

This assessment calls for both a presentation and accompanying written proposal.

Oral Presentation: No more than 5 minutes and 20 slides or less.

Written Proposal: Approx. 250 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"83018df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2018df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Work Installation and Catalogue Assets","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The artwork that you have produced will be assessed in the context of the exhibition. This will be done as a class group crit focusing on both the creative resolution of each work and the creative decisions or potential compromises made in the installation of the exhibition. Your capacity to effectively work as a team member will also feature as a component in the assessment criteria.

In week 8 you are required to generate an artist’s statement that clearly articulates your artwork in text. This must be accompanied by representative images suitable for the requirements of the catalogue.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9102 - Lens and Studio Craft","description":"

In this course you will begin to explore the expressive potential of lens-based practices and develop basic practical understandings of analogue, digital and video cameras. You will be introduced to the foundational techniques in working with different camera technologies to produce studio outcomes utilising both operational possibilities and restrictions of the chosen technology. You will be expected to undertake training in the Health and Safety aspects of studio work and comply with relevant requirements as part of developing a professional approach to practice. This course covers camera operation, lighting equipment and the physical properties of film and video in the context of contemporary fine art practices. You will be encouraged to situate your own work in relation to historical precedents and the continually evolving critical debate around lens based practices. This course froms part of the Temporal and Spatial Practices studio focus. This studio is intended to develop or consolidate technical skills and expand your capacity in constructed or directorial modes of image making across photography, video and other temporal and spatial practices.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c0214137db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Disposition of light","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The theory of Humors suggests that the human body is filled with four substances that influence our well-being and in-effect creating four temperaments: phlegmatic; choleric; sanguine; melancholic. This project asks students to consider light as a creative element to construct four images that reflect these temperaments using the psychological implications of light and its capacity to evoke mood. Use the Iconologia of Cesare Ripa as a platform for thinking about allegorical symbolism to consider the arrangement of pictorial devices such as lighting, focus, angle of view - as well as the scene, props and object/model you employ to communicate your idea.  Produce a set of 4 photographic prints or equivalent (at a scale(s) deemed appropriate to the conceptual intent). Alternatively/in addition you may work with moving image and use in camera editing and postproduction to perform some treatment to the exposure, colour balance and tone of footage if required. 

Project 2 will involve image research, lighting diagrams/sketches, practical assessment and time management, production management i.e. location management, weather forecasting, props, makeup, models, working with a team.

Students are required to undertake and complete one planned shoot per week in the studio. Evidence of studio experimentation, as well as contextual and theoretical research, must be undertaken by each student in the form of a visual journal. Students are required to uploaded excerpts of their working process from their journal to the class Moodle Blog weekly. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c214137db391c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88214137db391c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c4214137db391c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3b114137db391c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"From darkness to light","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This project asks students to explore light as an image making tool – beginning in darkness and ending in light. A photographic image is gradually built up as light hits the film emulsion or the digital sensor. In controlling the amount of light, its direction and intensity together with the controls of the camera, an image is produced that removes the scene from moment of reality as directed by the artist.  

The concept of photography - or to ‘draw with light’- preempts a relationship with the way in which we represent an object in a space by the creative controls of a camera in a particular lighting situation. Students are encouraged to experiment with various combinations of time (aperture and shutter speed) and continuous light sources to determine the appropriate exposures and the subsequent mood of the image in a series of creative works equivalent to 5 photographic prints (at a scale(s) deemed appropriate to the conceptual intent). 

Students are required to undertake and complete one planned shoot per week in the studio. Evidence of studio experimentation, as well as contextual and theoretical research, must be undertaken by each student in the form of a visual journal. Students are required to uploaded excerpts of their working process from their journal to the class Moodle Blog weekly.

contentlets.keywords: art,fine art,studio practice,photography,video art,digital photography,analogue photography
contentlets.description: In this course you will begin to explore the expressive potential of lens-based practices and develop basic practical understandings of analogue, digital and video cameras. You will be introduced to the foundational techniques in working with different camera technologies to produce studio outcomes utilising both operational possibilities and restrictions of the chosen technology. You will be expected to undertake training in the Health and Safety aspects of studio work and comply with relevant requirements as part of developing a professional approach to practice. This course covers camera operation, lighting equipment and the physical properties of film and video in the context of contemporary fine art practices. You will be encouraged to situate your own work in relation to historical precedents and the continually evolving critical debate around lens based practices. This course froms part of the Temporal and Spatial Practices studio focus. This studio is intended to develop or consolidate technical skills and expand your capacity in constructed or directorial modes of image making across photography, video and other temporal and spatial practices.
contentlets.title: Lens and Studio Craft

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9104 - Additive Approaches to Art","description":"

 



This practical studio class introduces you to the technical and material processes of working creatively to produce an object or work of art by adding or aggregating materials. It introduces the techniques and technologies of three-dimensional printing, casting and mould making and their potential applications and possible implications for contemporary art and object making. The relevant Health and Safety issues will be addressed in order to develop a professional and  self-sustaining approach to studio practice. The course addresses modelling and construction techniques using a variety of materials and emphasises the historical and contemporary context of images made by the addition or aggregation of diverse materials. The Addition and Aggregation Atelier develops or builds on existing skills in students who wish to begin or continue working spatially. The course is taught in the studio through a system of lectures and practical studios and tutorials.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9106 - Temporal Approaches to Art","description":"

 Temporal Approaches to Art is one of four courses available in Temporal and Spatial Practices Stream in the Master of Art. It provides an opportunity for postgraduate art students to explore in more detail the ways in which time, change and transformation can be employed in their work. Building on Additive Approaches to Art, the course introduces ideas of flow, change and transformation, which have been critical to modernist and contemporary art practices. The focus is on exploring these key facets of art and experience in developing new approaches to art making. 


Attention will be given to exploring models of collaboration along with both new and traditional processes of making art. These process include video, animation, sound art, interactivity, and performance. The course is intended to build on a your existing knowledge while extending and challenging established ways of thinking and making art.


The course is studio based and taught through a system of lectures, tutorials and studio practice where all teaching and learning revolves around the act of making and physical engagement.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1f51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"It's About Time","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Time operates across all modes of creative expression and is equally present in a painting (collapsed time) as it is in an animation (streamed time).  The student is to explore temporality as a creative agent in how a work of art is developed.  They are to research and develop a proposal for a significant project that reflects their understanding of temporality and how it shapes the nature and meaning of an art work of their own.


Feedback will be provided by the lecturer in class both during the development and production of the work.  Additionally structured, lecturer lead peer-to-peer critical feedback will be provided prior to assessment to enable the candidate to consolidate their existing creative processes by critically engaging with their peers in the studio.

The student is to plan and successfully finish a substantial work of art that reflects their understanding of the attributes and characteristics of a temporal approach to a contemporary fine arts practice.  


Feedback will be provided by the lecturer in class both during the development and production of the work.  Additionally structured, lecturer lead peer-to-peer critical feedback will be provided prior to assessment to enable the candidate to consolidate their existing creative processes by critically engaging with their peers in the studio.  Written feedback will be provided to each student on completion of the subject that addresses the approach they have chosen to the coursework and to the outcomes achieved. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1351c937db391c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d351c937db391c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Time Will Tell","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Temporal approaches to art making can be best mastered by correctly working with the terms and concepts that are keys to understanding the agency of time within a work of contemporary art.  You are required to identify at least one key term and concept and to appropriately work with them in making a work of art of your own that reflects a comprehension of how these terms and concepts are applied to practice


Feedback will be provided by the lecturer in class both during the development and production of the work.  Additionally structured, lecturer lead peer-to-peer critical feedback will be provided prior to assessment to enable the candidate to consolidate their existing creative processes by critically engaging with their peers in the studio.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f51c937db391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9106.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
Temporal Approaches to Art is one of four courses available in Temporal and Spatial Practices Stream in the Master of Art. It provides an opportunity for postgraduate art students to explore in more detail the ways in which time, change and transformation can be employed in their work. Building on Additive Approaches to Art, the course introduces ideas of flow, change and transformation, which have been critical to modernist and contemporary art practices. The focus is on exploring these key facets of art and experience in developing new approaches to art making. 

Attention will be given to exploring models of collaboration along with both new and traditional processes of making art. These process include video, animation, sound art, interactivity, and performance. The course is intended to build on a your existing knowledge while extending and challenging established ways of thinking and making art.

The course is studio based and taught through a system of lectures, tutorials and studio practice where all teaching and learning revolves around the act of making and physical engagement.
contentlets.title: Temporal Approaches to Art

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9115 - Fine Arts Professional Practice","description":"

Fine Arts Professional Practice prepares postgraduate students for professional practice as artists (or as arts-related professionals).
The course provides an overview of professional practice in Australia, including such topics as: the arts infrastructure and 'industries'; arts and cultural policy and funding; legal and commercial frameworks; professional ethics; intellectual property and copyright; service organisations, unions and professional organisations.


The course also introduces Master of Art students to some of the skills needed for establishing professional practice, including: small business organisation and management; taxation, finance and accounting; planning, marketing and promotion; preparation of applications (for grants, studios, scholarships), submissions (exhibitions, projects), documentations of work, and curriculum vitae.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a7318537db391c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research & Proposing a Self-Initiated Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Working in a small group the student will identify an appropriate Neutral/White cube venue or historically resonant site for which they will propose an individual or group project.  The written proposal will detail their theme as well as the social and cultural value of their proposed project and its relationship to contemporary art and ideas in an Australian and regional context.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"13318537db391c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3318537db391c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"47318537db391c50eb6b147a3a961946","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Producing, Developing & Resourcing your Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The student has researched and written a formal exhibition or project proposal (from task 1) and the next stage is to write an appropriate grant application, business feasibility study or other appropriate form of funding strategy that can enable its production.  This fund raising initiative must be reconciled to a realistic timeline and budget and be supported by a C.V. and relevant images.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ab318537db391c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f318537db391c50eb6b147a3a96194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Documentation & Advocacy for Self-Initiated Projects","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This group project consolidates assessment tasks 1 and 2 by examining forms of exhibition design, documentation and promotion that are developed by artists to present and advocate for their self initiated exhibition or project. Working within your existing team each member researches possibilities relevant to the topic and evaluates them relative to the range of strategies that are current and relevant. The findings are collated into a PowerPoint presentation that is delivered and assessed in class by the lecturer and peer reviewed by another team. 50% (15% of 30%) of the groupwork mark is provided by another team or group through a peer review process and 50% (15% of 30%) provided by the lecturer.  The team provides the total mark for each individual in the team though no individual can participatate in evaluating themselves.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9203 - Chromatic & Tonal Approaches to Contemporary Art","description":"

In this course you will begin to explore the inter-related properties of colour and tone with regard to their applications in contemporary image making. This investigation will be informed by historical precedents in order to articulate your studio practice in relation to various frames of reference. By contrasting colour with black and white, this course will examine the outcomes different chromatic and tonal approaches produce across the disciplines of painting, photography, drawing and video. 


This course deals with the evolution of colour theory and the important role considerations of light and dark, black and white continue to play in contemporary image making. It draws on the scientific and physiological influences that have shaped theories of colour and tone and their fundamental role in picture making and image composition.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"02110137db391c50eb6b147a3a961964","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Temperature","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task focuses on developing your understanding of temperature as a fundamental property of both chromatic and monochromatic modes of composition. This task requires you to produce two works. You will first produce one colour or monochromatic work of your choice. By experimenting with the temperature of elements within the image, you will then ‘revision’ this image into a further work which you consider has a different meaning or effect. This task requires you to present both works and to explain how your changes to the temperature of elements has altered its meaning or effect. An explanation statement of your approach is to be documented in a 1-page statement (500 words), printed out and displayed alongside your work. The statement will be required to succinctly address the following:  

  • explain your key intentions regarding meaning or affect in your first image
  • what was your intention for altering temperature in your second image (i.e. what changes to meaning or affect were you seeking?)
  • what formal means did you employ to achieve this?
  • to what extent do you consider the changes you've made to image two successfully realise these intentions?

Your experimentation is to be documented in your Visual Diary entries. You are also required to respond to the Weekly Provocation Blog (Week 8-10).

Submission details:

  • Visual Diary - Post at least three entries per week (text / images of work-in progress) Weeks 8-10
  • Weekly Provocation Blog - Post at least one entry per week (100-150 words) and respond to at least one peer’s post per week Weeks 8-10
  • Hand in your two artworks and your one-page statement (hard copy) on assessment day
  • Upload your one-page statement and at least two high quality images of your work online on the day of assessment.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"06110137db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9110137db391c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c6110137db391c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d110137db391c50eb6b147a3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Value","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment task focuses on developing your understanding of value (tone) as a fundamental property of both chromatic and monochromatic modes of composition. This task requires you to produce two works. You will first produce a colour image of your choice. Using analysis and experimentation, you will then ‘remake’ your colour image in monochrome so that the two images are consistent in value. This task requires you to rethink your colour image with regard to its tonal properties without the assistance of software to automatically schematize the image’s information. Your experimentation is to be documented in your Visual Diary entries. You are also required to respond to the Weekly Provocation Blog on Value (Week 1-3).

Submission details: 

  • Visual Diary- Post at least three entries per week (text / images of work-in progress) Weeks 1-3
  • Weekly Provocation Blog - Post at least one entry per week (100-150 words) and respond to at least one peer’s post per week Weeks 1-3
  • Hand in your two artworks on assessment day
  • Upload at least two high quality images of your installed work online on the day of assessment
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"06110137db391c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9110137db391c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c6110137db391c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9110137db391c50eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Light","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment task focuses on developing your understanding of light (transparency/opacity) as a fundamental property of both chromatic and monochromatic modes of composition. This task requires you to produce two works. You will first produce one colour or monochromatic work of your choice. By experimenting with the transparency and opacity of elements within the image, you will then ‘revision’ this image into a further work which you consider has a different meaning or effect. This task requires you to present both works and to explain how your changes to the transparency and opacity of elements has altered its meaning or effect. An explanation statement of your approach is to be documented in a 1-page statement (500 words), printed out and displayed alongside your work. The statement will be required to succinctly address the following:  

  • explain your key intentions regarding meaning or affect in your first image
  • what was your intention for altering light in your second image (i.e. what changes to meaning or affect were you seeking?)
  • what formal means did you employ to achieve this?
  • to what extent do you consider the changes you've made to image two successfully realise these intentions?

Your experimentation is to be documented in your Visual Diary entries. You are also required to respond to the Weekly Provocation Blog   (Week 4-7).

Submission details:

  • Visual Diary - Post at least three entries per week (text / images of work-in progress) Weeks 4-7
  • Weekly Provocation Blog - Post at least one entry per week (100-150 words) and respond to at least one peer’s post per week Weeks 4-7
  • Hand in your two artworks and your one-page statement (hard copy) on assessment day
  • Upload your one-page statement and at least two high quality images of your work online on the day of assessment.

contentlets.keywords: art,fine art,studio practice,photography,video art,digital photography,analogue photography
contentlets.description:
In this course you will begin to explore the inter-related properties of colour and tone with regard to their applications in contemporary image making. This investigation will be informed by historical precedents in order to articulate your studio practice in relation to various frames of reference. By contrasting colour with black and white, this course will examine the outcomes different chromatic and tonal approaches produce across the disciplines of painting, photography, drawing and video. 

This course deals with the evolution of colour theory and the important role considerations of light and dark, black and white continue to play in contemporary image making. It draws on the scientific and physiological influences that have shaped theories of colour and tone and their fundamental role in picture making and image composition.
contentlets.title: Chromatic & Tonal Approaches to Contemporary Art

This capstone course provides you with the opportunity to research and develop a comprehensive body of work, which combines  your studio specialisation studies with the specific framework for professional practice and management you have evolved to express your artistic identity. Your project should respond to an issue, dilemma or problem, from which you develop a concept and solution relevant to the aspirations you have for professional practice or further higher research based study. You will work in an interdisciplinary studio environment and have access to a variety of creative approaches that will support a self sustaining  approach to individual or multidisciplinary creative authorship.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1337387bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation of Proposal for Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The Capstone Project is a substantial body of work (equivalent of 12 units of credit) undertaken in any art/design/media medium. It should demonstrate: independent investigation and research; originality of concept; experimentation and development; involving high level production values and a refined/resolved outcome. Example projects will be shown and discussed in early lectures. 

Students present the Proposal for the Capstone Project body of work they will undertake supported by a short paper (250 words submitted via Moodle) describing the process to be undertaken. Initial feedback is direct and provided in a one on one critical session with the lecturer augmented by peer-to-peer review. Additional written feedback against criteria is provided.

Feedback is direct and provided in a one on one critical session with the lecturer augmented by peer-to-peer review. Additional written feedback against criteria is provided.

Completion of body of work, the Capstone Project, along with its presentation and/or exhibition in appropriate venue for general and specific audiences,  supported by a short paper (500 words submitted via Moodle) describing the outcomes of the work.

Feedback is direct and provided in a one on one critical session with the lecturer augmented by peer-to-peer review. Additional written feedback against criteria is provided.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9205","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9205 - Project Paper","description":"

This course enables students to write a paper of approximately 3,000 to 5,000 words that complements the major work undertaken in the Capstone Project course.  Students will research a selected subject, or subjects, related to the their studio practice and interests. Subject to approval, the work undertaken will be initiated by the student.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6c310537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation & Statement of Intended Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

A.    Students make a short Presentation of Intended Research about their work and their research question or topic. It must respond to the assessment criteria and include mention of influences, lineage, fields and context in relation to literature or discourse. The presentation should be approximately 5 minutes and include about 10 images.

B.     Write a Statement of Intended Research of approximately 500 words, plus images and bibliography. Include a mix of references including high quality sources such as books, book chapters and journal articles, cited using the Harvard intext method (or another style, pending approval). 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20310537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"60310537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"10310537db391c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment asks you to submit an annotated bibliography, providing an overview of the sources you intend to utilize in your paper. Your submission should include a 200 word introduction followed by a list of at least 7 sources (books, book chapters, articles, high quality websites, exhibitions,  etc) with a short (100 – 150 words) explanation of how each source contributes to your paper.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"24310537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"58310537db391c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Final Paper. The paper should be 3,000 to 4,000 words in length, follow the conventions of scholarly writing and develop from the course’s assessable and non-assessable tasks.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9206 - The Serial Image: Making Prints","description":"

This course supports innovative and experimental print based practices by technically and conceptually supporting a dialogue between printmaking and photography. Through lectures, tutorials and by demonstration you will learn to print black and white photographs and to make Intaglio and Screen prints. Experimentation in combining various approaches and techniques to the serial image will be supported by project based assessment that enables you to work in an interdisciplinary way within the expanded field of the hand made print. The Occupational Health and Safety procedures that enable you to work proficiently in the film development, photographic dark rooms and printmaking studios will be addressed.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8a043073dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961966","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"On Message: The Media and Print","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Photography has many similarities between it and printed media, both in the fine art world as well as the commercial sphere. Its ability to be (nearly) endlessly reproduced mechanically has positioned these analogous techniques on a knife’s edge – balancing somewhere between authenticity and reproduction, high art and low culture.

This Assessment Task harks back to the Canadian philosopher and intellectual Marshall McLuhan, who coined the phrases ‘the medium is the message’ and the ‘global village’. Since the advent of the World Wide Web (Mc Luhan predicted it 20 years earlier), he has been looked at with renewed interest. Fifty years ago, he was mus ing abo ut ho w media s erved to extend the human brain but few unders to o d what he was talking about. In advancing a theory in which the medium becomes more important than the content presented in it, artists as a consequence have explored the relationships between medium and content - particularly in the past two decades when the internet and digital media have pro liferated. The Internet makes clear what Mc Luhan was s aying, for he suggests that revolution takes place as personal and social life adjusts to new models of perception produced by new technologies. From the alphabet on there has been a continuous drive in the west toward a separation of the senses, which has had a profound impact on our emotional and political existence.

What constitutes a print today as opposed to 50 years or even 500 years ago? Understanding that the print, in its long history, has always been at the cutting edge of communicating ideas and developments in technology. This project will require the creation of a printed artwork using photographic serigraphy techniques, that responds to the idea of the media being more important than the message. Examine the relationships between The Media (in its broadest sense), its content and contemporary everyday life. This can take the form of but is not limited to criticism, exploration of ethical concerns, aesthetic and philosophical theory. Investigate the visual vernacular of The Media (Newspapers, advertising, billboards, product packaging, blogs, facebook, twitter, instagram…) and create an image consisting of at least 4 colours and referencing the graphic tropes of the commercial world (Examples of these are: CMYK colour separation, halftones, pixels, emoji, glitch art, digital icons, menu bars and brand logos). While the format size of the image is up to each student it is recommended that it is no larger than A4.

Artists to look at include - Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstien, Chuck Close, Alison Alder, Nam June Paik, Técha Noble, Tom Sachs , Kristan Von Hornsleith, Elmgreen and Dragset.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0a043073dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3904fc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Repurpose","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Old negatives and prints found and purchased at markets, in second-hand stores or on eBay are often used by artists as valuable source material for the production of new works. As the idea of reproduction is bound both to mechanical processes and to photography, many printmaking processes also incorporate photo-based methods to realise images in serial form. A print from a photographic negative can be endlessly reproduced, but to what end? As a strategy to examine meaning or for reflective thought, artists will take both their own photographs and/or use pre-existing ones.

This project requires you to consider the pre-existing or found photograph as a catalyst for the production of a small series. It seeks to incorporate the processes of reproduction and repetition in order to draw our attention to ideas of similarity/dissimilarity and uniqueness/difference. Find or acquire a negative that has been lost, unclaimed or discarded and produce a set of four darkroom prints. Explore the extent to which an unfamiliar image can be reworked and reinterpreted to generate new meanings and alternative propositions from that of the original.

Artists to investigate include –John Baldassari, Broomberg & Chanarin, Tacita Dean, Patrick Pound, Walid Raad, Kiki Smith and Akram Zaatari.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"46043073dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f9043073dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6104fc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Hybrid Print","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The presence of one category of image within or on top of another is a process of hybridization. The hand colouring of etchings, woodblock prints and more recently black and white photographs and postcards have long been activities undertaken by industry professionals (master printers, studio photographers) as well as studio based artists. The combination of two or more distinct technical process in a print is both historically well established and more recently a highly contemporary form of image or culture jamming.

The intervention into one form of image by an artist using processes that are not intrinsic to it has become a source of great creative potential for artists working individually and collaboratively. It is to bring interdisciplinary methodologies and practices to bear as a way of cohering or hybridizing an image. This project requires you to intervene in a printed image (photographic or serigraphic, found or self generated) with either another printing process or by other means that are relevant to the growth and direction of your own aesthetic or creative interests. You are to try to explore the possibilities of alternative readings, narrative ambiguity and a sense of wonder and magic.

Artists to investigate include - Gerhard Richter, Esther Teichmann, Izabela Pluta, Fabienne Rivory, Phil George, Darren Sylvester, Tara Marynowsky, Joan Ross, Sarah Contos, Phil James, David Noonan, Michael Callaghan, Arnulf Rainer.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"82043073dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7104fc33dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9206.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9207 - Line and Mark: Past & Futures","description":"

In this course you will explore the expressive potential of line and mark-making in the production of contemporary creative studio work. It will develop both your technical skills and conceptual understanding of image making. Drawing is foregrounded as an experimental and conceptual process informed by history and the rich potential offered by new ways of thinking. Line and Mark: Past & Futures provides instruction and insight into the creative and symbolic potential of gesture and mark making essential to linear processes. You will be expected to be aware of important Health and Safety aspects of studio work and comply with relevant requirements as part of developing a professional approach to practice. This course forms part of the Planar Practices studio focus. The course is taught in the studio through a system of lectures and practical studios and tutorials.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9704 - The Laptop Atelier","description":"

Digital technologies have transformed how art is created and displayed. This course supports students to develop an art practice that engages with everyday digital technologies. The course introduces students to the creative possibilities of digital, interactive, mobile and embedded technologies in the context of new models for art making in the 21st century.


 


  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"355b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interaction Workshop","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Over 2 weeks a series of intensive workshops will be undertaken in class, focussed upon using Isadora, to create interactive artworks. This assessment is designed to encourage students to develop an understanding of some of the strategies that can be used to create responsive systems through a process of experimentation. 

Students can use other software that they are otherwise already familiar with such as PD or MAXMSP but support in the workshops is focussed upon Isadora. 

Students will present a small art project that interactive in form.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"695b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"115b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are asked to submit a 1000 word written proposal describing the approach they plan to take in their Final Project for Assessment 3.  The proposal should include a description of the conceptual, aesthetic, and technical approaches that will be undertaken, taking into account a consideration of the audience's experience. Proposals should summarise the process of experimentation undertaken to date and aim to be realistic and appropriate to the students technical skills while also challenging students to extend those skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a55b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"595b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Create an interactive art work that uses digital means in its construction or reception. Cross-disciplinary,experimental and hybrid forms are encouraged. You may include elements that have no digital or technological means. Project may include experimental video, video or sound installation, performance, interactive installation or art object/s in 2 or 3 dimensions but must be interactive in some form. All work must be within the genre of fine art practice. Informational, commercial, graphic design, advertising and music clips may not be presented for assessment unless it is to critique or challenge these genres within art practice.

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9708","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9708 - Figure and Figuration: Mapping the Body","description":"

This course looks at the intersection of contemporary art practices with theories and visual representations of the body. Through studio-based learning, you will explore ways in which painting, drawing, printmaking and photography can respond to personal, social, and political constructions and discourses about the gaze, objectification, gender, sexuality, and identity. You will develop a studio practice that explores the complexities of figure and figuration, supported by independent research.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9e5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Project: Thematizing the Body","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

In this Assessment Task, you will initiate and develop a body of studio work that evidences advanced enquiry within areas of drawing, painting, printmaking, photography, or inter-disciplinary practices. You will imaginatively interpret concepts and themes relevant to ‘Figure and Figuration’ that reflect (i) your individual interests, (ii) your exploration of personal, social, and political constructions of the body, the gaze, objectification, gender, sexuality, and identity, and (iii) your understanding of art historical and contemporary discourses and developments within the field. 

To undertake this task, possible concepts, themes and visual representations of the body will emerge from course lectures and reference material. More specifically, research and resources deposited within your ‘Mapping the Body: Research Archive’ will underpin your studio work. 

Your assessable artwork(s) will be supported by an ‘Artist’s Statement’ that expresses the conceptualization (ideas), contextualization (references), and methodologies (processes) underpinning your project. The statement will include the title of the project, the details/medium of the work, and a description (300 words). The Artist’s Statement is non-assessable, and is considered part of standard professional practice: it will assist academics with the assessment of your work. 

Assessable artworks and relevant support material are to be displayed in the studio during your scheduled class time, accompanied by an Artist’s Statement. An electronic record of the Assessment Task must also be uploaded via Moodle ‘Assignments’ within 24 hours of the studio assessment. Format: PDF file with embedded artist’s statement, text and images. File name: SURNAME_FirstName_SART9708_Task_3.pdf.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"525b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9e5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Encountering the Figure","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

During this Assessment Task, various theoretical, conceptual and thematic constructions, discourses, and images will be introduced, allowing you to ‘encounter the figure’. These will frame various studio experiments, allowing you to explore ideas and engage with diverse materials, processes, and analogue and digital technologies (drawing, painting, photographic, printmaking, collage, montage) that will position your production within discipline-specific and expanded fields of practice. These studio intensive sessions might introduce you to new materials and assist you to develop creative and technical strategies when undertaking Assessment Task 3. 

Primary images created by yourself and secondary source images (from newspapers, magazines, Fine-Art reproductions, video/film stills, photography, graphics, illustrations, the internet) will be collected, reimagined, manipulated and combined throughout these sessions, allowing for expressive and interpretative mediations. They will be assessed as a portfolio that show engagement with various materials, imaging and/or fabrication techniques; reflection within studio practice; and creative thought, conceptual insight, and interpretation of the introduced themes and discourses. 

Assessable artworks and relevant support material are to be displayed in the studio during your scheduled class time. An electronic record of the Assessment Task must also be uploaded via Moodle ‘Assignments’ within 24 hours of the studio assessment. Format: PDF file with embedded text and images. File name: SURNAME_FirstName_SART9708_Task_1.pdf.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"525b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9e5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mapping the Body: Research Archive","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will engage in independent research to support, contextualize, and elucidate your self-directed studio practice. The task will constitute a record of your responses to lecturesand the evolution, progression, and finalization of ideas and art making processes associated with Assessment Task 3. 

The vehicle for this task is the ‘Mapping the Body: Research Archive’, accessed through your UNSW Moodle course blog. This blog/journal/archive can be thought of as a site to uploadpreliminary thumbnail sketches, studies, and photographs of artworks in progress: it is to be thought of as a site for responding to lecture material and collecting texts and images, references and reflections that map and present your ideas and self-directed research. The archive will evidence an understanding and investigation of concepts, theories, historical and contemporary practices, and artists of interest and influence (their images, philosophies, and processes). Material should be annotated with comments, and images should be captioned with information such as names of artists, titles, dates, etc. It will include excerpts from books and peer-reviewed articles concerning the figure and its discourses (relevant to the course and to your practice). There is an expectation you will upload material to the blog between Week 2 and its assessment in Week 9: there should be a minimum number of eight (8) individual entries.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"da5b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c25b7077dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619be","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9708.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Through studio-based learning, you will explore ways in which painting, drawing, printmaking and photography can respond to personal, social, and political constructions and discourses about the gaze, objectification, gender, sexuality, and identity. You will develop a studio practice that explores the complexities of figure and figuration, supported by independent research.

Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9727","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9727 - Drawing","description":"

This course will provide the opportunity for students at any level of drawing experience to investigate many aspects of drawing. Students will explore a range of visual images and ideas supported by an examination of historical and contemporary drawing practice. Through interpreting and translating two and three dimensions students will develop observational skills and begin to build a personal graphic language.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8b410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing from Direct Observation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will draw from direct observation to gain an understanding of the conceptual and perceptual challenges of representing three-dimensional objects on a two-dimensional ground. Students will be introduced to basic perceptual analysis strategies such as measuring, plotting, gridding, using positive and negative space, and methods of construction drawing. Concepts such as proportion, viewpoint, foreshortening, and perspective will be explored and visually applied. The assessment task will run for three (3) days and will include one (1) home project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"87410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Understanding Tone, Form and Volume","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In this assessment task, students will use tone to create the pictorial illusion of ‘three-dimensionality’. Through a process of intense observation, students will enhance their ability to create volumetric form; identify reflected light on objects; differentiate planes and solids by establishing tonal relationships; moreover, express tonal grades across light, mid-tone, and dark objects, and lit or shadow areas. Modeling techniques may include hatching, cross-hatching, contour hatching, block tone, and working from dark to light by employing an eraser as a drawing tool. The assessment task will run for three (3) days and will include one (1) home project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exploring Colour, Surface, and Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

While focusing on colour, surface, and form, this project will introduce students to various materials and working processes, expand their drawing practice and style, and develop their compositional skills. Through a process of intense observation, students will visually represent structure and surface by identifying and responding to variations in the tones and hues of objects and their shadows, reflected light, and both matte and lustrous, plain and patterned, smooth and textured surfaces. Students will use various drawing techniques, materials (such as pastels, pencils, and watercolours) and a colour palette that allows them to express these subtleties. This assessment task runs for four (4) days. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"87410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76410937db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9727.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Through interpreting and translating two and three dimensions students will develop observational skills and begin to build a personal graphic language.

Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9728","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9728 - Painting","description":"

This subject will introduce students to basic skills in painting and encourage them to understand both the inter-relationship of form and content and the creative possibilities of various media and techniques. Students will explore aspects of contemporary art practice and develop an understanding of the historical development of painting. This course will use a series of projects and workshops to extend the student's personal creative interests.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e2410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site/Place","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students are to research and document a site/place familiar to them; an interior, exterior, domestic, urban, or landscape scene they can make repeat visits to. The emphasis is on the collection of PRIMARY source material, i.e. research and documentation including notes, rubbings, plein-air paintings and sketches undertaken by the student in situ. Photographic documentation is not permitted. In contrast to 'Secondary Source Painting', all images that derive from the subject in the development of the work are to be entirely of the student's own authorship. Students will then paint a studio-based work using this primary research.

Students must consider how direct experience of the subject informs the meaning of their work. For example, the conceptual rationale for such a process of direct experience could engage with concepts of 'connectedness to land' or the notion of 'home' and its associated themes of autobiography and identity. Questions regarding the ‘nature’ and ‘mode’ of engagement with the subject are significant, for example, being mindful of the appropriateness of different types of investigations, the gathering of different types of research material, and the various observational, perceptual, intellectual, or emotional experiences with a subject that will meaningfully contribute to the creation of a painting. Students may choose to explore phenomenological/perceptual themes in response to experiential sensations linked to site/place. Phenomena and atmospherics related to light, environment, and climate, for example, may be relevant in this respect, whether the site is ‘natural’ or ‘built’. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"06410937db391c50eb6b147a3a961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Painting From Direct Observation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Painting a still life from direct observation, two small ‘canvases’ will be completed: each will depict the same two or three objects but with different compositional viewpoints. The objects (of the student’s choice) might be similar to each other (e.g. three teapots) or contrasted (e.g. star fish and mechanical apparatus). Aspects to consider when selecting the objects are colour, pattern, texture, scale, form, materiality, simplicity or complexity, their decorativeness or utility, and even their symbolic or personal associations. Pictorial concerns of cropping, composition, scale, and viewpoint will be a focal point of both paintings, with contrasts between: (I) the ‘macro’ and ‘micro’ viewpoint — in this instance, defined as a view that is all-encompassing and broad in scope, versus a more closely focused view with small- scale sections made large, even to the point of abstraction — and (II) ‘open’ and ‘closed’ compositions — defined as compositions where forms extend outside of the picture plane, versus those where objects and forms are largely (and often formally) contained within the frame. An introduction to painting techniques and materiality is also a feature of this assessment task, with a range of approaches including preparation of a ground, sketching, under-painting, painting wet-on-wet, wet-on-dry, and glazing, to be considered by the student. An introduction to colour theory will also allow the student to mix colours to appropriately reflect the range of tones and hues within the still life. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1a410937db391c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9e410937db391c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"da410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"82410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96190d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Secondary Source Painting","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This task requires a creative response that focuses on the interpretation of secondary source material (defined as ‘found’ or ‘pre-existing’ images created by another individual or entity), including images and text from newspapers, magazines, books, Fine-Art reproductions, video/film stills, photography, industrial and commercial graphics, illustrations, and computer-generated imagery.

Students will respond to their found image(s) through a series of processes, translating their 2- dimensional source material into a 3-dimensional structure, then into a painting. For the purpose of this task, a 3-dimensional response might take the form of an image or collage (manipulated or composed of low-relief, projective, folded, bent, creased elements), an assemblage, construction, model or diorama. The student may paint directly from the model, or photograph the model and refer only to the photograph whilst painting, mindful that any method employed will influence the appearance of the final image. In this sense, ‘Secondary Source Painting’ is a protracted mediation of the subject, and can involve several degrees of separation between the ‘original’ source material and the student's painting.

Through the processes and conventions of ‘sculptural’ fabrication, photography, and painting, students will develop creative strategies through which they can deconstruct, reconstruct, transform, interpret and critique their secondary source image(s). Students will be mindful of aesthetics, content, and meaning while addressing a spectrum of issues such as form, composition, materiality, spatiality, scale, lighting (modeling, light and shadow), and depth of field (focus and lack of focus). The fluidity of authorship, notions of ‘originality’, and the establishment of meaning through the modification, recycling or remixing of cultural forms is also a feature of this task. For assessment you will be required to present all relevant found image(s), model(s), photographs (if applicable), and painting. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"52410937db391c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"da410937db391c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ca410937db391c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9728.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Students will explore aspects of contemporary art practice and develop an understanding of the historical development of painting. This course will use a series of projects and workshops to extend the student's personal creative interests.

This subject will introduce students to basic procedures and attitudes in the contemporary art practice of etching. Through lectures, demonstrations and projects, students will gain understanding and skills in the use of traditional and contemporary techniques in etching as a means of creating unique and original works of art. After gaining understanding and proficiency in established approaches, students will be introduced to current developments in photo-etching and solar plate etching.

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9740","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9740 - Anatomy for Artists","description":"

This course will provide a study of the human form through the investigation of comparative anatomy, skeletal structure and musculature and a perspective on the history and philosophy of anatomical images as reference to contemporary practice. A practical examination of the structure, form and function of the body will develop an understanding of the human figure. The course will also include the study of canons of proportion and cultural perceptions of the body. Emphasis will be placed on direct observations of the nude and anatomical specimens. Students will draw from the skeleton, casts and prepared specimens. A range of approaches will be covered that will encourage students to understand basic anatomical constructs. This course is designed to be relevant to a broad range of student interests from a variety of disciplines.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9744","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9744 - Fine Arts Field Trip","description":"

This course is designed to enable students with a particular interest in the natural environment to devote an extended and concentrated time in the field to researching a remote location. By direct encounter and observations, students will deal with the natural world as an invaluable resource of ideas and inspiration particularly relevant to the focus of their major studies. Students will be encouraged to investigate, identify and document new material that they can gather in the field that will be most relevant to developing new work back in the studio.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Trip Studio Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The students will work on and extend their initial field trip research back in the studio.

This means making more work related to the initial proposal started in the field or by using other strategies such as changing their methodology once back in the studio.

This final outcome might look like a different body of work but must have a direct relationship to the research done in the field.

10% of the 40% will be devoted to effectively engaging with the ‘Moodle’ online platform by posting updates at least five times in the gallery section of the students profile, which should include commentary on other students work. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"08418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8c418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3f318537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

The student is to research and start a body of work that is based on their experience of the particular environment of Fowlers Gap research station.

This body of work will be based on a proposal that is negotiated with the lecturers (by Day 3). The proposal is worth 10% of the 60% total.

Each student must have at least two meetings with the lecturers in the field so as to be clear about their proposal's direction. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8c418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c0418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c8418537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f3318537db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9744.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SART9745","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9745 - Custom Printing","description":"

This unique postgraduate course emphasises printmaking as a collaborative and community-oriented practice. The course introduces etching (intaglio) processes in the setting of an artist residency program, providing opportunities for you to work with visiting artists in the studio. Previous printmaking skills are not essential to undertake this course. Through studio-based assessments you will begin to develop the practical skills and conceptual frameworks necessary to incorporate printmaking into your creative practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"eb47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961995","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Book","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This Assessment Task requires you to produce an editioned image, developed from an interpretation of a thematic brief. This task introduces the matrix (plate) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) as it pertains to the editioning systems and technical procedures encountered in the Custom Printing course.

This Assessment Task, will involve plate production in the first 3 weeks, and from Week 4 editioning sessions will be organized as an introduction to specific custom printing routines. Feedback will be provided on student’s bon à tirer proofing prints in week 3.

In carrying out this task students will contribute to the supportive and constructive workshop environment fostered by the Custom Printing course. You will seek to establish verbal communication skills appropriate to your developing artistic practice and the processes encountered in a number of forums. This will include individual consultation with the lecturer or active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others.

Specific information on the thematic brief and technical requirements for submission are provided in the assessment brief available on the course Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6347a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Print Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task will introduce you to print portfolios, a convention of printing. Just as printmaking consists of particular printmaking processes, it also fosters certain structural formats that have evolved over its history and continue to assert themselves in contemporary art practice. A print portfolio may consist simply of a series of prints, aligned by a common theme and published as a group. Such a series will often be housed in a folder, a bound range of pages or a designated art portfolio.

This project, in suggesting the production of a portfolio, will be exploring a format which has been popular, certainly over the past centuries, but has also benefited from a contemporary resurgence in artist’s collaborative participation and curatorial interest. Multi-component print projects can also be produced by groups of artists brought together to produce individual pieces for a single object/book. Such artworks can be produced to represent social causes or political issues as well as personal explorations of more intimate themes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a347a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"af47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5347a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supporting Artist Residencies","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Supporting Artist Residencies provides students with the opportunity to meet and work with artists in the development of print related work in the research group Cicada Press. This assessment task requires students to contribute to the collaborative working relationship between the artist and custom printer by being actively involved in the plate production, proofing and editioning for the artists invited to participate in this course.

Students will be divided into 3 working groups that will be scheduled to work after the completion of Assessment Task 1 – Alter Ego in Week 5. The rostered groups will be available on a one week on and two weeks off basis. These groups will be on duty from 10am to 5pm on their rostered days to assist the lecturer and invited artists in the associated work routines aligned with matrix development and editioning. Students will be assessed on their individual contribution during their time on duty in the scheduled group contact with the resident artists and associated activities.

The range of technical activities that each student will encounter will provide invaluable skills based training at industry standard. All students who participate in an editioning session will receive a Printers Proof (P/P) of each print for their contribution. All efforts will be made to ensure an equal distribution of editioning tasks to all participants within the class. Much of the editioning will need to be scheduled outside of class time. Students are to collect their Printers Proofs from Rebecca O'Shea on Fridays, once the prints have been signed by the artist. Rebecca will normally be in attendance during the scheduled class.

Please note that the artists will be attending all day, if possible students are encouraged to attend for the full day on their rostered days.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ef47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9b47a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961973","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/SART9745.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Previous printmaking skills are not essential to undertake this course. Through studio-based assessments you will begin to develop the practical skills and conceptual frameworks necessary to incorporate printmaking into your creative practice.

Building on your previous experiences in printmaking, this postgraduate course asks you to assume a leadership role in the setting of an artist residency program, providing opportunities for you to work with visiting artists in the studio. Continuing to emphasise printmaking as a collaborative and community-oriented practice, this course advances your abilities as a skilled and creative facilitator, able to collaboratively assist other artists in a printmaking setting. Through studio-based assessments and collaborative workshop processes you will develop advanced practical skills and conceptual frameworks to integrate printmaking into your creative practice.

This course will enable students from a variety of backgrounds to acquire skills in the production of artists' books, folios and other limited edition publications. Examples of the different kinds of historical and contemporary artists' publications will be examined. A variety of materials, skills and techniques, both traditional and contemporary and alternative, which are involved in book and folio production will be researched and demonstrated. Students will have the opportunity to produce an artists book which could have a relationship to their core studies.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9751 - Electronic Technologies","description":"

This is a workshop based course which aims to provide the student with investigative and practical skills in the application of low voltage electricity to contemporary sculptural practice. Basic understanding of power source and linking will precede instruction in the use of small motors and lighting units. This will progress to practical exercises in the use of simple computer boards and an understanding of the incorporation of such specific technologies into practice. Emphasis will be placed on direct observations of the nude and anatomical specimens. Students will draw from the skeleton, casts and prepared specimens. A range of approaches will be covered that will encourage students to understand basic anatomical constructs. This course is designed to be relevant to a broad range of student interests from a variety of disciplines.

Basic understanding of power source and linking will precede instruction in the use of small motors and lighting units. This will progress to practical exercises in the use of simple computer boards and an understanding of the incorporation of such specific technologies into practice. Emphasis will be placed on direct observations of the nude and anatomical specimens. Students will draw from the skeleton, casts and prepared specimens. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SART9754 - Metal Casting","description":"

This workshop based course is for those students seeking to resolve investigations into theories and concepts by means of bronze casting and mould making. Through lectures, demonstrations and projects, students will investigate mouldmaking processes of increasing complexity and to cast various metals, especially bronze. The theory of metal casting will be discussed as it applies to individual work required by the student within the context of contemporary practice.

Through a series of studio based projects students will gain a knowledge of historic and contemporary models of abstraction as well as an understanding of formal developments as they apply to drawing and painting.
